Identify companies or corporations that have been accused or indicted of price fixing including the product or type of product involved.  

Relevant documents must contain both the company and the product involved. Documents about price fixing by the stock market are not relevant.


You are a strict classifier for "corporate price-fixing cases."

RELEVANT if all of these hold:

- The document names a specific company or corporation accused, charged, or under investigation for price fixing.
- It identifies the product or product category subject to the alleged price-fixing scheme.
- It refers to an accusation, indictment, settlement, fine, or legal proceeding related to the price-fixing allegation.

NON-RELEVANT if any of these hold:

- It only discusses price-fixing concepts or antitrust policy in the abstract without a concrete case.
- It concerns stock-market price fixing or securities market manipulation rather than goods or services pricing.
- It mentions a company or product but omits any legal action (accusation, fine, settlement).
- It covers industry pricing trends without reference to illegal coordination or enforcement actions.

RECORDINGS PLAYED IN TRIAL OF 3 EX-ARCHER OFFICIALS



   CHICAGO _ A Japanese agricultural executive identified two
former senior officers of Archer Daniels Midland Co. as having met
with him in a price-fixing conspiracy, on a day when secret
government recordings of pricing discussions were played in public
for the first time.


   The information emerged in the first day of evidence in the
trial of three executives who worked for ADM. The testimony and
recordings underscored the deep sense of distrust and dislike among
the companies that have already pleaded guilty to conspiring to fix
the price of lysine, a feed additive.


   In one document, an Asian lysine producer raised the possibility
of bombing Archer Daniel's lysine plant, to slow the company's
entry into the business. And, on tape recordings, a Japanese
executive discussed how a Korean company that had agreed to fix
prices ``by nature will tell a lie.''


   The government has charged the three former executives _ Michael
Andreas, the vice chairman who is on leave from the company;
Terrance Wilson, head of the company's corn processing division,
and Mark Whitacre, the head of its bioproducts division _ with
participating in the conspiracy from 1991 to 1995.


   The tape recordings were obtained from Whitacre, who became a
government informant less than a year after prosecutors say the
scheme involving Archer Daniels began. But he became a defendant in
the case after the government learned he had violated his
cooperation agreement by taking millions of dollars from Archer
Daniels.


   In the testimony, Kanji Mimoto, an executive with Ajinimoto Co.
of Tokyo, said that competitors in the lysine business had engaged
in price fixing long before Archer Daniels entered the market in
the early 1990s. But, he said, Archer Daniels executives were the
first to push efforts to control production volumes, which would
help guarantee the effectiveness of a price-fixing scheme.


   Many of the discussions on production floundered, however,
because of insistence by Archer Daniels that it be assigned as much
volume as Ajinimoto, then the largest lysine producer in the
business, Mimoto said.


   ``What I remember strongly, was that Terry Wilson said that as a
company policy, ADM must have the same share as the market leader''
under such an agreement, he said.


   In a later phone call, Mimoto said, Whitacre told him that he
was interested in increasing the price, even without a volume
agreement in place. That call took place before Whitacre began
working for the government.


   Two recorded calls with Mimoto, made by Whitacre after his
cooperation began, were played in court. At times in in recording,
the men used fictitious names. In the first, the two men haggled
over how high lysine prices should go. In the second, Mimoto
expressed concerns about meeting in the United States because of
possible legal problems.


   ``We know that in the United States the antitrust statutes are
very severe,'' he said in the recording. ``So, as much as possible,
we wanted to avoid the United States.''


   Earlier in the day, Reid Weingarten, a lawyer for Wilson,
presented his opening statement. In it, he said that the words of
Wilson captured on tape were not what they appeared, largely
because his client was lying to the competitors in an effort to
break up the Asian cartel.


   As evidence, he cited a secretly recorded statement made by
Wilson late in the investigation that he said proved there was no
true price-fixing effort. ``If we were trying to fix prices,''
Weingarten quoted him as saying, ``Then we ought to be fired'' for
incompetence. &QL;

PRICE-FIXING TRIAL OPENS FOR 3 EX-ARCHER OFFICIALS 



   CHICAGO _ In opening arguments in one of the largest
price-fixing trials ever, a federal prosecutor said Wednesday that
former senior executives with Archer Daniels Midland Co. ``were
caught red-handed'' on secret recordings conspiring with
competitors to set the market prices for a popular feed additive.


   But a defense lawyer for one of the executives challenged that
claim, saying that the recordings of his client had captured very
little, and that meetings the government portrayed as incriminating
involved little more than discussions about the functioning of the
market for the additive, lysine.


   In the opening statements, the two sides disclosed for the first
time that price fixing in the lysine market predated the entry of
Archer Daniels in the business, involving a small cartel of
Japanese and other Asian companies. And a defense lawyer also said
that, during investigation the government's chief informant on at
least one occasion secretly taped an FBI agent involved in the
case.


   Three former executives from Archer Daniels _ Michael D.
Andreas, the former vice chairman who is on leave from the company;
Terrance Wilson, the former head of the company's corn processing
division, and Mark E. Whitacre, the former head of its bioproducts
division _ were charged by the government as participating in the
conspiracy.


   But it is Whitacre who will clearly be at center stage
throughout most of the trial. It was Whitacre who first disclosed
the price fixing between the competitors and who secretly recorded
conversations over two and a half years. But he became a defendant
in the case after the government learned he had violated his
cooperation agreement by taking millions of dollars from Archer
Daniels, even as he was working with law enforcement officials.


   Over more than an hour, the prosecutor, James M. Griffin,
methodically described the government's evidence, as he led the
jury through a narrative of the major meetings during which the
lysine competitors agreed to fix prices and allocate production
volumes among themselves.


   Griffin said that to prove the crime the government had only to
provide evidence that an agreement to fix prices had been reached.


   ``The agreement is the crime,'' he said. ``It does not matter if
the conspirators kept the agreement.''


   Griffin said that the government would prove that price fixing
was nothing new at Archer Daniels. For example, he said that one
witness would testify that Wilson had been fixing prices on citric
acid, a food additive, since 1991, before the lysine scheme began.


   Griffin added that the taped evidence alone proved the roles of
Andreas and Wilson. ``Michael Andreas and Terry Wilson were caught
red-handed on audio and videotape committing the crime they are
charged with,'' he said.


   But John Bray, a lawyer for Andreas, said that there was no
compelling recordings clearly proving that his client had engaged
in wrongdoing, and that he was innocent. ``If ever there was a
case, ever, where there are two sides to the story, then this is
it,'' Bray said.


   Rather than encouraging lawbreaking, Andreas was trying to take
on the illegal Asian cartel, Bray said. At times, he said, his
client can be heard on tape saying that Archer Daniels ``does not
make deals'' with competitors relating to price and volume.
Moreover, Bray said, the tapes that do exist are ambiguous as to
their meaning.

extortion story, which he said Whitacre had concocted for his own

 Cargill Cleared of Price-Fixing 


	SAN FRANCISCO (AP) -- A federal appeals court cleared Cargill  
Inc. on Wednesday of taking part in an international conspiracy to 
fix the price of citric acid. 


	The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals refused to reinstate a  
damage suit by soft drink companies and other buyers of citric acid 
that was dismissed by a federal judge last year. 


	The court said there was no evidence Cargill, a leading  
processor and distributor of agricultural, food and industrial 
products, conspired with four other major firms that admitted 
agreeing to divide markets and set prices. 


	One of the four, Archer-Daniels Midland, pleaded guilty in 1997  
to conspiring to fix prices of citric acid and lysine, an animal 
food additive, and was fined $100 million, then the largest 
criminal antitrust penalty on record. 


	The other three companies, Haarman & Reimer, Hoffman LaRoche and  
Jungbunzlauer, also pleaded guilty to criminal charges. A number of 
employees have been prosecuted, including three senior ADM 
executives who were sentenced to prison in July. 


	All four companies also settled civil suits by bottlers and  
processors. 


	But Cargill, based in Minneapolis, insisted it had no part in  
any conspiracy and simply followed a common practice of basing its 
prices on those of its competitors. 


	Citric acid, with worldwide sales of $2 billion to $3 billion a  
year, is used to extend the shelf life of soft drinks, canned 
fruits and vegetables, detergents, drugs and cosmetics. 


	The four companies admitted agreeing between 1991 and 1995 to  
divide the market and raise prices by limiting sales. 


	Cargill entered the market in the late 1980s and gained a 20  
percent U.S. share by the mid-1990s. 


	The suit, a class action by Varni Brothers Corp. and the 7-Up  
Bottling Co. of Philadelphia, accused Cargill of joining the 
conspiracy in 1993 when it joined the European Citric Acid 
Manufacturers Association, a group to which the other four 
companies belonged. 


	The suit noted that Cargill had announced in early 1992 that it  
planned to double its citric acid production capacity but announced 
in late 1992 that it would increase capacity only 50 percent. The 
suit also cited an FBI report in one of the criminal cases that 
quoted Barrie Cox, an ADM employee, as saying he had frequent 
discussions with Cargill's national sales director about citric 
acid bidding prices in 1995. 


	But the appeals court largely discounted Cox's statements,  
saying they showed, at most, ``sporadic price discussions'' two 
years after Cargill was alleged to have joined the conspiracy. 


	Cargill's scaling back of its expansion plans, and its posting  
of prices that largely mirrored those of its competitors, were not 
evidence of a conspiracy, said Judge Diarmuid O'Scannlain in the 
3-0 ruling. He said Cargill's expansion of its U.S. market share 
came largely at the expense of ADM and Haarman & Reimer. 


	Of the companies that admitted fixing prices, ``none identified  
Cargill as a co-conspirator,'' O'Scannlain said. 


	Therese Stewart, a lawyer for the companies that sued Cargill,  
said the court disregarded an earlier antitrust decision and made 
it extremely difficult to get a price-fixing conspiracy case to 
trial. Even ``evidence of actual agreement between an admitted 
conspirator and the defendant on certain bid prices'' isn't enough, 
she said, referring to the FBI's statement from Cox. 


	But Richard Favretto, a lawyer for Cargill, said Cox's  
statements were never corroborated and were considered by the 
federal government in a four-year investigation that cleared the 
company. 


	The ruling is ``a further vindication of our position,'' he  
said.

VIDEOTAPES TAKE STAR ROLE AT ARCHER DANIELS TRIAL 



   CHICAGO _ Top executives from two of the world's most powerful
food companies sat at a conference table, snacking on orange juice
and steak sandwiches as they spoke. The meeting, in a private room
at the Marriott Hotel in Irvine, Calif., was terse and
businesslike. But the topic of discussion, the government says, was
a crime.


   For several hours, the four men _ two from Archer Daniels
Midland Co. and two from Ajinimoto Co. of Japan _ haggled over
volume production numbers, arguing over the accuracy of data they
were providing each other about their companies' sales of a feed
additive. It was, prosecutors say, the critical stage in conspiracy
that had lasted more than a year to fix prices of the additive.


   And unknown to all but one man in the room at that meeting in
October 1993, every word was being videotaped.


   More than three years after government raids disclosed the
existence of a huge price-fixing investigation, prosecutors played
that videotape Monday to a federal jury that is hearing the
criminal price-fixing case against three former Archer Daniels
executives. All three men have pleaded not guilty.


   If the government is right in its claims, the videotape offers
an unprecedented look into what the government contends was a
price-fixing conspiracy on a giant scale, involving every major
company in the business of producing the additive, which is called
lysine. It shows the executives of the two largest companies in the
business discussing how they would dictate the annual growth in
production to the other lysine makers, and debating the tactical
benefits of simply lying to the others about certain data.


   But the tape has already played a critical role in reshaping the
future of Archer Daniels, the politically powerful grain giant. For
it is the crucial evidence against one defendant, Michael Andreas,
the son and former heir apparent to the powerful company's
chairman, Dwayne Andreas.


   Also charged in the case are Terrance Wilson, the former head of
the company's corn-processing division, and Mark Whitacre, the
former head of its bioproducts unit, which produces lysine.


   The government has already secured guilty pleas from some of the
executives involved in the conspiracy and each of the companies;
Archer Daniels agreed to pay $100 million in 1996 to settle
price-fixing charges.


   Since the investigation was first disclosed, much of the public
attention has focused on Whitacre, who served as a government
informant during the inquiry and secretly recorded his colleagues
over more than two years. But he became a defendant in the case
after the government learned he had violated his cooperation
agreement by illegally taking millions of dollars from Archer
Daniels through a complex fraud.


   Indeed, much of the defense centers on Whitacre. Lawyers for
Andreas and Wilson have argued that he manipulated investigators
and Archer Daniels officials to create evidence of a conspiracy.

into providing information that would allow Archer Daniels to gauge

 Vitamin Co. To Plead Guilty 


	WASHINGTON (AP) -- A Canadian company agreed Wednesday to plead  
guilty and pay a $5 million criminal fine for its role in an 
international conspiracy to fix prices on vitamin B-4. 


	The Justice Department said the agreement is part of its ongoing  
investigation into a global conspiracy to rig prices for certain 
vitamins. 


	Chinook Group Limited of Toronto was accused of conspiring with  
other businesses to raise and fix prices for vitamin B4 in the 
United States and other countries from January 1988 through 
September 1998. The Justice Department said Chinook also conspired 
to divide the market for the vitamin during that time. 


	Vitamin B-4 is used primarily in animal feed.  


	Joel Klein, Justice's antitrust chief, said the case shows the  
government's ``continuing resolve to thwart illegal activities that 
harm American businesses and consumers, regardless of the location 
of the culprit.'' 


	The one-count criminal case was filed in U.S. District Court in  
Dallas.

7 FIRMS IN $1 BILLION SETTLEMENT OF SUIT ON VITAMIN PRICE-FIXING 



   Seven of the world's largest drug and pharmaceutical companies
agreed Wednesday to pay more than $1.1 billion to settle a
class-action lawsuit that sought damages as a result of an
international conspiracy to fix vitamin prices.


   The settlement, which was submitted to a federal judge in
Washington for approval, is thought to be the largest civil
settlement ever in a class-action antitrust case. It comes just
months after the companies agreed to pay record fines in settling a
criminal complaint from the Justice Department.


   The seven companies had been accused in both cases of plotting,
for nearly a decade, to artificially inflate the prices of the raw
vitamin blends that go into everything from milk and breakfast
cereal to animal feed. The blends involve vitamins A, C and E and a
variety of the B-complex vitamins, including beta-carotene.


   The class-action case was brought by direct purchasers of bulk
vitamins, including some of the world's largest food, beverage and
animal feed companies, like Kellogg, Kraft and Tyson Foods.


   The settlement payments are expected to compensate those
purchasers, rather than ordinary consumers.


   As indirect purchasers of raw vitamin mixtures, consumers have
been overpaying for everything from vitamin tablets to the small
portions of vitamins added into everyday foods. But although
lawyers involved in the case say consumers may be compensated as
part of state class-action suits pending against the vitamin
makers, few think any such settlements would be as large as the
private settlement that was announced Wednesday.


   The vitamin makers, several of which have already settled
government charges in Canada, are also facing antitrust
investigations in Europe.


   As a result of the conspiracy, which lasted from 1990 to 1998,
the seven companies had already agreed to pay nearly $2 billion in
government and class-action settlements for fixing the prices of
vitamins in the United States.


   The companies that settled Wednesday are Roche of Switzerland,
BASF of Germany, Rhone-Poulenc of France, Hoechst Marion Roussel of
Germany, Takeda Chemical of Japan, Eisai Co. of Japan and Daiichi
Pharmaceutical of Japan. The settlement figure represents a penalty
of about 20 cents on every dollar in sales by the seven companies
during the period in question, lawyers involved in the case said.

their involvement in the conspiracy and would like to put it behind

lawsuits,'' a spokesman at BASF said.

Europe and implemented in the U.S., that fixed prices and carved up

VITAMINS  
(DW)



   The Justice Department said Thursday that three Japanese
pharmaceutical companies had agreed to plead guilty to U.S.
antitrust violations and to pay more than $137 million to settle
charges that they took part in a worldwide conspiracy to fix prices
in the vitamin market.


   The settlement comes just months after three European vitamin
manufacturers _ some of the biggest and best-known pharmaceutical
and chemical companies in the world _ agreed to pay huge criminal
fines for what government prosecutors say was a decadelong
conspiracy to inflate the price of vitamins used in everything from
breakfast cereal to hand cream.


   In breaking up the cartel, the U.S. government has now recovered
more than $850 million and exposed a loose confederacy of vitamin
makers that met clandestinely for years, plotting in hotel rooms
and other places to divide up world markets and to artificially
increase the price of vitamins that were sold to virtually every
food, beverage and animal feed company in the world.


   The case does not involve the sale of vitamin tablets, commonly
sold at a drug store, but the ingredients that go into everything
from vitamin tablets to poultry feed and orange juice.


   Although the companies that have confessed to taking part in the
conspiracy account for more than 90 percent of the world's vitamins
sales, it is unclear whether American consumers will receive any
compensation for purchasing products that, year after year,
contained over-priced albeit small vitamin ingredients. Several
class-action suits brought by large food makers and various other
groups could eventually benefit consumers.


   The guilty pleas came from Takeda Chemical Industries of Osaka,
which agreed to pay $72 million; the Eisai Co. of Tokyo, which
agreed to pay $40 million, and the Daiichi Pharmaceutical Co. in
Tokyo, which agreed to pay $25 million, according to the
government. Takeda is the largest pharmaceutical company in Japan.
No executives were charged.


   Takeda, which sold vitamins B and C, released a statement late
Thursday saying it deeply regretted the matter and that any
employees involved in the case would be disciplined. The company
said all managers, executives, board members and an auditor would
have their pay reduced.


   Officials at Daiichi, which sold vitamin B, could not be reached
for comment.


   Cathy Pollini, a spokeswoman at the U.S. subsidiary of Eisai,
which sold vitamin E, said Thursday that she could only confirm
that the company was cooperating with the Justice Department's
investigation of anti-competitive practices in the vitamins market.

demonstrates the truly international aspect of the vitamin

 US Wins Vitamin Price Fixing Case 


	WASHINGTON (AP) -- A Swiss vitamin manufacturer and five U.S.  
executives have agreed to plead guilty to participating in a 
worldwide conspiracy to fix the prices of vitamins, the Justice 
Department announced Tuesday. The company agreed to pay a $10.5 
million fine. 


	The corporation, Lonza AG, was charged in previously sealed  
court documents with scheming to fix the prices and allocate the 
sales of vitamin B3, also known as niacin and niacinamide, the 
department said. 


	The five executives were charged Tuesday with plotting to fix  
prices and allocate customers and sales of vitamin B4, also known 
as choline chloride. 


	Both vitamins are used to enrich human and animal nutritional  
products and are sold around the world. 


	These were the first cases made public from the antitrust  
division's investigation of the vitamin industry. Both the company 
and the executives agreed to cooperate in the continuing probe, 
which is centered in Dallas, where the charges were filed in U.S. 
District Court. 


	``The cooperation of these defendants, in combination with  
information being provided by others who are cooperating, will 
substantially advance the division's investigation of international 
cartels in the vitamin industry worldwide,'' said Deputy Assistant 
Attorney General Gary R. Spratling. 


	This is the latest in a series of international price-fixing  
cases brought by the division in recent years, including 
prosecutions in the food and animal feed additives industry which 
obtained record fines. 


	``These charged are the latest example of the antitrust  
division's commitment to prosecuting international cartels that 
increase prices for American consumers,'' said Assistant Attorney 
General Joel I. Klein. ``Our investigation into worldwide 
conspiracies involving vitamins is continuing. Those conspiracies 
have affected billions of dollars of commerce in products found in 
nearly every American household.'' 


	One count was filed Tuesday against each of the following:  


	--John Kennedy, vice president of sales and marketing, Chinook  
Group Inc., a U.S. subsidiary of Chinook Group Ltd., a Canadian 
company. 


	--Robert Samuelson, sales manager, Chinook Group Inc.  


	--Lindell Hilling, former president, DuCoa L.P.  


	--J.L. ``Pete'' Fischer, president, basic and international  
products, DuCoa L.P. 


	--Antonio Felix, vice president, basic and international  
products, DuCoa L.P. 


	Each was charged with scheming with unnamed co-conspirators to  
eliminate competition in the choline chloride market in this 
country and elsewhere between at least January 1988 through Sept. 
29, 1998. 


	Each man is charged with agreeing to set prices, rig bids,  
allocate customers, divide world markets, and monitor and enforce 
the agreed-upon prices and market shares. 


	The Lonza case, filed under seal last Sept. 30 and unsealed  
Monday, charged that Lonza executives agreed with the world's other 
major vitamin B3 firms to eliminate competition here and elsewhere 
at least from January 1992 until March 1998. Specifically, the 
company was accused of agreeing to set prices, allocate sales 
volume between competitors and enforce these agreements. 


	All the defendants were charged with violating the Sherman Act,  
which carries a top penalty of $10 million for corporations and 
three years in prison and a $350,000 fine for individuals. The 
maximum fine for both may be increased to twice the gain derived 
from the crime or twice the loss suffered by victims, if those

 Japanese Firm To Pay $21M Fine 


	WASHINGTON (AP) -- The Japanese chemical company Nippon Goshei  
agreed today to plead guilty and pay a $21 million criminal fine 
for participating in a 17-year international conspiracy to fix the 
price of food preservatives known as sorbates, the Justice 
Department announced. 


	In addition, a former Nippon Goshei executive agreed to plead  
guilty and pay a $350,000 fine, the department said. 


	Nippon Goshei will become the third company to plead guilty and  
cooperate with the ongoing investigation by the department's 
antitrust division of the plot it says affected nearly $1 billion 
of sales in the United States alone. 


	Last October, Eastman Chemical Co., a U.S. sorbate producer,  
pleaded guilty and was fined $11 million. Last month, the German 
pharmaceutical giant Hoechst AG also pleaded guilty and was fined 
$36 million. 


	Sorbates are used to preserve cheese and baked goods, or other  
high-moisture or high-sugar, dairy and processed foods. 


	A one-count criminal information was filed in U.S. District  
Court in San Francisco charging the company and the executive with 
conspiring the raise and fix prices and allocate market shares 
between competitors in the sale of sorbates from 1979 to 1996. 


	``This was an incredibly long-lived international conspiracy,''  
said Deputy Assistant Attorney General Gary R. Spratling, the 
antitrust division's enforcement chief. 


	The executive is Hiromi Ito, former marketing and sales director  
of Nippon Goshei's Fine Chemicals Business Department. He also has 
agreed to cooperate with investigators. 


	``The department will continue to seek out and prosecute all  
international conspiracies that defraud American consumers and 
unfairly restrain free and open competition in our markets,'' said 
Assistant Attorney General Joel I. Klein. 


	The court document charged the company and Ito violated the  
Sherman Act by meeting with competitors to raise and set prices for 
sorbates sold in this country and abroad, allocate market shares 
and exchange price data to police the agreements.

reached an agreement with federal prosecutors to pay a record $725

conspiracy to raise and fix the prices of vitamins, according to 
lawyers familiar with the case. 


	A $725 million settlement would be the largest criminal fine  
ever obtained in any type of federal case in U.S. history, 
officials said. 


	The total settlement will top the $100 million paid in 1997 by  
Archer Daniels Midland Co., the U.S. agribusiness giant, for its 
role in fixing prices for two food additives, lysine and citric 
acid, according to a Justice Department official who requested 
anonymity. 


	Roche Holding AG of Switzerland agreed to pay $500 million, and  
BASF AG of Germany agreed to pay $225 million, officials said. 


	Attorney General Janet Reno, antitrust chief Joel I. Klein and  
his criminal enforcement director, Gary Spratling, were to announce 
the deal at a news conference later today. Asked whether the 
department was settling with two vitamin companies, Reno told her 
weekly news conference this morning, ``An announcement should be 
made later this morning.''

the Justice Department's antitrust division under which prosecution 
can be avoided if the company volunteers evidence of its role in 
price-fixing before prosecutors learn of it through their 
investigations, Justice officials said.

JURY SAYS 3 EX-EXECUTIVES OF ARCHER DANIELS FIXED PRICES 



   Three former executives with Archer Daniels Midland Corp. _
including the son of its powerful chairman, Dwayne Andreas _ were
found guilty Thursday of engaging in an international conspiracy to
fix the prices of a widely used additive for animal feed.

victory for prosecutors, capping a six-year effort by the

VITAMIN MAKERS SAID TO AGREE TO PAY $1.1 BILLION TO SETTLE SUIT 



   Six of the world's largest vitamin makers have agreed to pay
about $1.1 billion to resolve a class-action lawsuit that accused
them of taking part in a global conspiracy to fix vitamin prices
over the past decade, people close to the talks said Tuesday.


   The settlement, which could come as early as this week, would be
one of the largest antitrust payments made in a private
class-action suit in U.S. history, lawyers close to the case said.


   There are still some tense negotiations under way, but if the
case is resolved, the six companies would all but admit that for
much of the past decade they artificially hiked the prices of
vitamins that went into everything from breakfast cereal and orange
juice to animal feed.


   The lawsuit was brought by some of the world's largest food,
beverage and animal feed companies. It accused the vitamin makers
of forming an international cartel that met regularly in hotel
rooms, sometimes under the fictional name ``Vitamins Inc.,'' to
divide up the global market and artificially hike the prices of a
wide range of vitamins, including Vitamins A, C and E, as well as
Beta-Carotene, essential ingredients in the diet of virtually every
American.


   ``There's an oral agreement on most material terms,'' said
Michael Hausfeld, one of the lead attorneys in the class-action
suit, which he said could be settled in the next few weeks. ``It's
a significant recovery as well as a demonstration of the
effectiveness of the antitrust laws.''


   The class-action suit was brought by direct purchasers of
vitamins for consumers, such as Coca-Cola, Kellogg's and Kraft
Foods Inc., as well as by the animal feed companies, which supply
vitamin-supplemented rations for poultry and livestock. The
companies would have to decide whether to pass on settlement
proceeds to consumers but are not obligated to do so. Consumers,
who are indirect purchasers of vitamins, are pursuing their own
settlement in a number of class-action suits at the state level.


   If a final agreement is reached in the next few weeks, it would
come just months after two European pharmaceutical and chemical
giants _ Hoffman LaRoche, part of Roche Holding AG in Switzerland,
and BASF AG of Germany _ agreed to pay $725 million, the largest
antitrust fine in history, to settle similar price-fixing charges
brought by the Justice Department. Roche paid $500 million of that
sum, with BASF paying the rest. A third big European company,
Rhone-Poulenc SA of France, was accused of being part of the
conspiracy but the company avoided paying a fine because it
cooperated with the Justice Department investigation.


   All three European companies _ which produce more than 80
percent of the world's vitamins _ have been negotiating to settle
the private class-action suits, and will pay the bulk of the $1.1
billion settlement, which was first reported Tuesday in the
Washington Post.


   Three Japanese companies, Daiichi Pharmaceutical Co., Eisai Co.
and Takeda Chemical Industries Ltd., are also part of the
settlement talks.

negotiations. But an official at Hoffman-LaRoche said the company
had already set aside $640 million to settle civil class-action
suits. ``Negotiations are under way, and we think it will be
settled soon,'' said Martin Hirsch, a spokesman at Hoffman-LaRoche.

Tuesday that the company was also moving toward an agreement. ``It
is our desire to reach a comprehensive settlement and to put this
matter behind us,'' he said. ``We are in negotiations but it is
premature to discuss the likelihood of success.''

more than $1.1 billion to settle the lawsuits, with about $125
million being set aside for attorney fees. The three European
companies would pay the bulk.

ARCHER EXECUTIVE TESTIFIES TO FIXING CITRIC ACID PRICES 



   CHICAGO _ An executive withArcher Daniels Midland Co. testified
Wednesday that he and another senior executive at the grain giant
had participated in a global conspiracy with competitors to fix the
price of citric acid, a widely used food additive.


   The testimony of Barrie Cox, an executive with the food
additives division of Archer Daniels, came in the criminal trial of
three former officers of the company who were charged with fixing
the price of lysine, an additive in animal feed.


   While no one in the case has been charged with fixing prices of
citric acid, the government sought Cox's testimony to bolster its
charges in the lysine case, and to respond to defense arguments
that Archer Daniels executives adhered to antitrust laws, and were
more interested in cutting prices than fixing them.


   Prosecutors have argued that Archer Daniels executives used the
method of fixing prices of citric acid as a model in the subsequent
lysine conspiracy. They argued that both systems involved
allocating sales quantities to competitors, with almost identical
methods of reporting and auditing to insure the schemes were
working.


   The three executives on trial are Michael D. Andreas, the former
vice chairman of Archer Daniels; Terrance Wilson, the former head
of the company's corn processing division; and Mark E. Whitacre,
the former head of its bioproducts division.


   The role of Archer Daniels in fixing prices of the food additive
was no surprise _ the company pleaded guilty in 1996 to conspiring
to rig both the prices of citric acid and lysine. And Cox offered
testimony about citric acid to the government that year as part of
a deal to reduce Archer Daniels' fine, which was eventually set at
$100 million.


   In his testimony, Cox said that Wilson took a direct role in
fixing prices of citric acid. He said that he and Wilson traveled
to meetings with four other European competitors, where both
price-fixing and volume allocation were discussed.


   The system described by Cox was unusually detailed. The
conspirators referred to themselves as the G-5, which stood for the
``group of five.'' He said executives in the conspiracy were
characterized as being in two categories: ``sherpas,'' who attended
to the daily details of the scheme, and ``masters,'' who handled
broader strategy and planning.


   Cox testified that the scheme began in the spring of 1991 and
lasted through 1995. Often, he said, illegal meetings between the
citric acid producers were held in conjunction with official
meetings of a trade association, in order to provide the executives
with cover.


   At one point in the conspiracy, Cox said that he had a
discussion with Wilson about what would happen if the government
learned of the illegal scheme. He said that Wilson replied, ``If
ever any of this goes wrong, you're on your own.''


   Under cross-examination, Cox testified that he had learned
during his time at Archer Daniels that executives with his former
employer, Pfizer Inc., had held pricing discussions with
competitors in the past. But he said that he was not aware of those
discussions while he worked at the pharmaceutical giant.


   Archer Daniels bought Pfizer's citric acid business in 1990.
Pfizer officials did not return telephone calls seeking comment on
Cox's testimony.

Manhattan, lawyers for Sotheby's denied each of the allegations
contained in the civil complaint against the two auction giants.


   The response, filed on Wednesday, was the first formal denial
issued by the auction house since Christie's disclosed in late
January that it had turned over information to the Justice
Department, which is investigating a possible antitrust conspiracy
between it and Sotheby's.


   In exchange for its cooperation in the department's 3-year-old
inquiry, Christie's received a promise of leniency. The criminal
inquiry is continuing, and people close to the investigation have
said that Sotheby's was under pressure from prosecutors to reach a
plea agreement.


   Marcia Horowitz, a spokeswoman for Christie's, said on Wednesday
that the company had not filed its response to the civil suits but
would do so soon.


   The potential damages to both houses from the civil suits are
enormous. Litigants in antitrust cases can win triple damages, and
the tab could run into the tens of millions of dollars if the
plaintiffs are successful, antitrust lawyers said.


   The first civil suit was filed in federal court in Manhattan two
days after Christie's disclosed its agreement with the Justice
Department. Since then, at least 55 other actions have been filed

defrauded buyers and sellers through a secret price-fixing scheme.

Kaplan of the Southern District of New York.

of the two houses met secretly to fix the commissions charged to
buyers and sellers. They also contend that the executives agreed to
stagger and coordinate auction dates to avoid competing.


   According to the suits, the conspiracy robbed sellers and buyers
of the ability to negotiate better commissions.

unidentified employees had coordinated sale dates with their
counterparts at Christie's. But Sotheby's said the coordination was
designed to allow prospective buyers to attend sales at both
houses.

from shareholders. On Feb. 21, its chairman, A. Alfred Taubman, and
its chief executive, Diana D. Brooks, both resigned.

1998, and is privately held.

FOUR DRUG COMPANIES TO PAY $33 MILLION IN FINES 



   WASHINGTON _ Four drug companies have agreed to plead guilty to
taking part in an international conspiracy to fix vitamin prices,
and two former executives agreed to prison terms, Justice
Department officials said Friday.


   In addition, the companies _ Nepera Inc. of Harriman, N.Y.;
Reilly Industries of Indianapolis; and Merck KgaA and Degussa-Huls
of Germany _ agreed to pay a total of $33 million in fines, the
officials said.


   The four companies are the latest to plead guilty in the Justice
Department's long-running investigation of the worldwide vitamin
industry, whose leaders colluded for more than a decade to increase
the prices of bulk vitamins used in everything from breakfast
cereal to animal feed, officials said.


   Joel I. Klein, the assistant attorney general responsible for
antitrust prosecutions, has called the price-fixing operation _
which has snared some of the world's best-known drug companies _
``the most pervasive and harmful criminal antitrust conspiracy ever
uncovered.''


   The conspiracy, which officials traced to executives at Roche of
Switzerland and BASF of Germany, began in 1989 and grew to include
French and Japanese drug concerns. Because those companies have
operations in the United States, they were subject to prosecution
in this country.


   Overall, seven companies have agreed to pay nearly $2 billion in
government and class-action settlements for fixing the prices of
vitamins in the United States.


   Justice Department officials accused the four companies named
Friday of sharing sales and customer information, fixing prices and
carving up the market for common products like Vitamin C, niacin
and Vitamin B3.


   Merck KgaA, which is based in Darmstadt, Germany, and is
unrelated to the U.S. pharmaceutical company of the same name, has
agreed to pay a $14 million criminal fine for taking part in a
Vitamin C cartel between 1991 and 1995, officials said.


   Degussa-Huls, of Frankfurt, acknowledged setting prices of
Vitamin B3 for three years ending in 1995 and accepted a $13
million fine.


   Nepera, a unit of the Cambrex Corp., agreed to a $4 million
criminal fine for fixing prices of Vitamin B3 and niacin. Roger
Noack, the former president of Nepera, agreed to serve eight months
in prison and pay a $50,000 fine. David Purpi, a former vice
president of Nepera, agreed to serve one year and a day in prison
and pay a $100,000 fine, officials said.


   Reilly Industries accepted a $2 million fine for taking part in
the Vitamin B3 conspiracy.


   The companies divided up lucrative markets around the world and
held regular budget meetings to prevent cheating, officials said.

 Vitamin Makers To Pay $725M Fine 


	WASHINGTON (AP) -- Two giant foreign companies agreed Thursday to  
pay $725 million in fines for plotting to raise and fix the prices 
of vitamins used in virtually every American home and added to 
bread, milk and breakfast cereal. 


	The $500 million fine to be paid by F. Hoffmann-LaRoche Ltd., a  
Swiss pharmaceutical company, is the largest federal criminal fine 
ever imposed in any type of case, Attorney General Janet Reno told 
a news conference. 


	A German firm, BASF AG, agreed to pay a $225 million fine for  
its role in the conspiracy to increase vitamin prices in the United 
States and around the world. Both companies pleaded guilty in U.S. 
District Court in Dallas. 


	Reno and aides said Americans unwittingly paid hundreds of  
millions of dollars in illegally inflated prices for vitamins and 
food staples such as vitamin-enriched bread. 


	``On a daily basis for the past 10 years, every American  
consumer paid to eat and drink or use a product whose price was 
artificially inflated,'' Reno said. 


	The vitamin cartel was the ``most pervasive and harmful criminal  
antitrust conspiracy ever uncovered,'' said Assistant Attorney 
General Joel I. Klein, Reno's antitrust chief. 


	``The criminal conduct of these companies hurt the pocketbook of  
virtually every American consumer -- anyone who took a vitamin, 
drank a glass of milk or had a bowl of cereal,'' Klein said. 


	The cartel boosted the price of more than $5 billion in products  
sold in this country, he said. 


	The scheme lasted from January 1990 into February 1999. The  
plotters boosted the cost of vitamins A, B2, B5, C, E and beta 
carotene -- those most commonly taken as pills or added to enrich 
human foods like bread, milk, orange juice and breakfast cereal. 


	These illegal price increases also reached consumers through the  
cost of animal products, because the vitamins are added to animal 
feeds. The plotters are the world's largest producers of the most 
commonly used vitamins. 


	The former director of worldwide marketing for Hoffmann-LaRoche  
Vitamins and Fine Chemicals Division, Dr. Kuno Sommer, agreed to 
plead guilty to helping run the cartel and lying to Justice 
investigators in 1997 to cover up the scheme. 


	Sommer, a Swiss citizen, agreed to serve a four-month prison  
term and pay a $100,000 fine. ``For the first time in our history, 
a European national will plead guilty and, subject to court 
approval, will serve four months in prison'' for price-fixing, 
Klein said. 


	Another three Hoffmann-LaRoche executives and four from BASF  
were not given immunity under the agreements reached Thursday, and 
additional prosecutions are possible, said Gary R. Spratling, 
deputy assistant attorney general in charge of criminal antitrust 
enforcement. 


	The case was broken open when another conspirator,  
Rhone-Poulenc, SA, a French pharmaceutical company, began 
cooperating with Justice investigators several months ago, 
Spratling said. ``The information provided by Rhone Poulenc was 
what the division needed.'' 


	Rhone-Poulenc was accepted into the antitrust division's  
leniency program, which protects companies from criminal 
prosecution if they voluntarily report their involvement in a crime 
before prosecutors learn of their role. 


	But all the companies still could face private class-action  
lawsuits from victims of the scheme. Private lawyers already have 
met to discuss such lawsuits. 


	Rhone-Poulenc said its animal nutrition division ``acknowledged  
there were instances in the past in which the company's global 
business practices did not meet U.S. legal standards,'' but said 
changes have been made ``to ensure compliance.'' 


	Justice officials said the attempted cover-up was a factor in  
the larger fine for Hoffmann-LaRoche. In addition, Hoffmann-LaRoche 
was a repeat offender, Klein said -- caught earlier by the antitrust 
division in a global cartel that raised prices for the food 
additive and feed additive citric acid.

 Poultry Producers File Vitamin Suit 


	FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. (AP) -- Tyson Foods and more than a half-dozen  
other U.S. poultry producers filed a federal lawsuit alleging a 
worldwide conspiracy among vitamin producers to fix prices for a 
popular animal-feed supplement. 


	The lawsuit makes claims similar to those in a federal criminal  
case that resulted in a multimillion dollar settlement last week. 
It seeks to recover threefold the wrongful costs incurred by 
poultry producers, but does not list a dollar amount. 


	``We believe we are the largest consumer of choline cloride in  
North America. As far as the actual amount we're out, we believe it 
is significant,'' Tyson general counsel Les R. Baledge said today. 
He declined to give a damage estimate. 


	The lawsuit, filed Tuesday in Fayetteville, alleges that  
Germany's BASF AG and other companies engaged in a 10-year 
conspiracy to fix, raise and stabilize the price of choline, 
commonly known as vitamin B4, and to divide up the world market 
share. 


	Choline is one of a number of vitamins essential to the diets of  
poultry. It assists in the transportation of fat from the liver and 
also affects certain nerve functions. 


	BASF agreed last week to plead guilty and pay $225 million in  
fines for a worldwide price-fixing scheme involving vitamins A, B2, 
B5, C, E and Beta Carotene. Swiss pharmaceutical giant F. 
Hoffman-LaRoche Ltd., also agreed to plead guilty and pay a $500 
million fine. 


	In March, Swiss vitamin manufacturer Lonza AG and five U.S.  
executives also agreed to plead guilty in a worldwide vitamin 
price-fixing conspiracy. Lonza, which is to pay a $10.5 million 
fine, was charged in a scheme for vitamin B3. The five executives 
were charged with plotting to fix prices and allocate customers and 
sales of vitamin B4. 


	``This is the civil side of the justice department's criminal  
indictment,'' said Fayetteville lawyer John Elrod, representing 
poultry producers Simmons Food Inc. and Peterson Farms Inc. ``We're 
tracking on the civil side on behalf of the people who lost 
money.'' 


	The lawsuit contends a conspiracy existed from at least January  
1988 through September 1998 among companies involved in producing 
and distributing the food supplement. 


	The lawsuit alleges that the companies agreed to allocate  
customers, then either refrained from submitting bids or submitted 
collusive, non-competitive or rigged bids to supply choline. 


	``The intended result of this conduct was to leave the customer  
with only one non-competitive bid from which to choose, and to 
force the customer to purchase choline at the seller's inflated 
price,'' according to the lawsuit. 


	As a result of the conspiracy, the price of choline was 60 to  
100 percent higher than the prices before and after the conspiracy, 
the lawsuit said. 


	The lawsuit contends that the North American market was divided  
and allocated to Bioproducts Inc. of Akron, Ohio; Highland, 
Ill.-based DuCoa, which was a partnership operated by E.I. Dupont 
de Nemours Inc. and ConAgra Inc.; and the Chinook Group, 
headquartered in Toronto, Canada. 


	European markets, according to the lawsuit, were divided among  
BASF; Azko Nobel Inc. of the Netherlands; and UCB SA of Belgium. 


	Others named in the lawsuit include Japan-based Mitsui and Co.  
and affiliates of the various companies. 


	In addition to the antitrust violations alleged in the suit, it  
accuses the defendants of trying to fraudulently conceal their 
anti-competitive acts. 


	Plaintiffs include Springdale-based Tyson; Allens Hatchery Inc.  
of Seaford, Del.; Chocktaw Maid Farms Inc. of Carthage, Miss.; 
Georges Inc. of Springdale and its affiliates; Hudson Foods Inc., 
which was bought last year by Tyson; OK Industries Inc. of Fort 
Smith; Peterson, based in Decatur; Simmons, based in Siloam 
Springs; Sunshine Mills Inc. of Red Bay, Ala.; and Townsends Inc., 
of Millsboro, Del.

 Japanese Firms Fined $137M 


	WASHINGTON (AP) -- Three Japanese companies are the latest to  
face criminal fines for plotting to raise and fix the prices of 
vitamins used in nearly every American home. 


	The Justice Department announced Thursday that the companies had  
agreed to plead guilty and pay $137 million in fines for taking 
part in a worldwide conspiracy to control the prices of vitamins. 


	``This conspiracy artificially inflated the cost to virtually  
every American of such everyday necessities as milk, bread, orange 
juice and cereal, which were fortified with vitamins produced by 
these companies,'' said Joel I. Klein, assistant attorney general 
in charge of antitrust activities. 


	The companies fined were:  


	--Takeda Chemical Industries of Osaka, $72 million for conspiring  
to fix the price and allocate the sales of vitamins B2 and C. 


	--Eisai Co. of Tokyo, $40 million for conspiring to fix the price  
and allocate sales of vitamin E. 


	--Daiichi Pharmaceutical Co. of Tokyo, $25 million for fixing the  
price and allocating the sales of vitamin B5. 


	In May, the Justice department announced a $500 million fine to  
be paid by F. Hoffmann-La Roche Ltd., a Swiss pharmaceutical 
company, in the vitamin price-fixing investigation. That is the 
largest federal criminal fine ever imposed in any type of case. 


	In addition, the German firm, BASF AG, agreed to pay a $225  
million fine for its role in the conspiracy to increase vitamin 
prices in the United States and around the world. 


	And in March, Swiss vitamin manufacturer Lonza AG and five U.S.  
executives agreed to plead guilty to participating in the global 
vitamin plot. Lonza agreed to pay a $10.5 million fine. 


	Several of the companies also are defendants in a civil suit  
brought by the buyers of bulk vitamins. 


	Overall, the department said, the cartel boosted the price of  
more than $5 billion in products sold in the United States between 
January 1990 and this February. 


	Involved were vitamins A, B2, B5, C, E and beta carotene, the  
ones most often taken as pills or added to enrich foods. 


	Officials said the case was broken open when another  
conspirator, Rhone-Poulenc, SA, a French pharmaceutical company, 
began cooperating with investigators. Rhone-Poulenc was accepted 
into the antitrust division's leniency program, which protects 
companies from criminal prosecution if they voluntarily report 
their involvement in a crime before prosecutors learn of their 
role. 


	The department also announced that the Japanese firm Takeda has  
agreed to cooperate with its investigators looking into the food 
flavor enhancers industry.

EVIDENCE EMERGES ON INQUIRY INVOLVING ARCHER DANIELS 



   After more than three years of being shrouded in secrecy,
evidence from the government's investigation of a huge price-fixing
conspiracy involving Archer Daniels Midland Co. is emerging as the
first criminal case stemming from the inquiry heads to trial.


   The evidence, referenced in government records filed with the
U.S. District Court in Chicago, portrayed the conspiracy between
Archer Daniels and foreign competitors to fix prices of a feed
additive as a complex, often frustrating effort that involved
several of the company's most senior officers.


   During the efforts to hammer out a deal, according to the
government documents, competitors were invited to Decatur, Ill.,
for a lunch at Archer Daniels.


   Senior officers then provided the competitors with a tour of its
plant to impress upon them the company's ability to manufacture
mass quantities of the additive lysine. That would decrease the
worldwide price of lysine, cutting into all the companies' profits.


   Jury selection began Thursday in the criminal case against three
former Archer Daniels executives _ Michael D. Andreas, who is now
on leave as the vice chairman of the company, Terrance S. Wilson,
the former head of its corn processing division, and Mark E.
Whitacre, the former head of its bioproducts division. Opening
arguments are expected next week.


   But records filed recently by the government lay out a blueprint
of the prosecution's case, with a description of some evidence and
a detailed chronology of the events leading up to the federal raid
of Archer Daniels in 1995.


   Chief among the evidence described were recordings made by
Whitacre, who worked for more than two years as a government
informant. Whitacre first alerted the government to the conspiracy
in November 1992 and was offered immunity for his role as part of a
cooperation pact. But prosecutors withdrew his immunity after
learning that Whitacre had illegally taken millions of dollars from
Archer Daniels while working on the case.


   In pretrial hearings, lawyers for Wilson and Andreas have made
clear that they intend to attack the government's inquiry as shoddy
and Whitacre as an out-of-control informant. They contended that
Whitacre set up their clients, and that no price-fixing ever
actually occurred. Lawyers for both men did not return calls
Thursday.


   But the most compelling evidence described comes from the tapes.
Numerous conversations, at times laced with obscenities, portrayed
Wilson as being intricately involved in the pricing scheme. At
times, he was described as telling competitors that if they tried
to compete on price, Archer Daniels would increase its production
of lysine.


   ``If we start losing business because of price,'' he was quoted
as telling a competitor, ``then we will change our mind and do what
we have to do.''


   Frequently, Andreas, the son of the company's chairman, Dwayne
Andreas, was portrayed as an important strategist in the scheme.
The documents described repeated briefings of Andreas by Whitacre
on the progress of the scheme. During a briefing about one meeting
with competitors, Whitacre mentioned to Andreas that prices were
rising slowly, to 85 cents a pound. ``Did you mention the idea that
you might take it up another nickel?'' Andreas asked.


   At another meeting, Andreas was quoted as expressing frustration
about talks with competitors to control production levels. ``We got
to start vocalizing our displeasure with volume,'' he was quoted as
saying, adding that Archer Daniels had to tell competitors that
they ``promised us we'd have our share if we backed off to the
levels we talked about.''


   Other executives who have not been indicted in the case were
also portrayed as being aware of the scheme. For example, James
Randall, the former president of Archer Daniels, was described as
having attended the tour of the Archer Daniels plant with
competitors, during which the benefits of price fixing were
discussed by Wilson. That conversation was not recorded.

 Lawsuit Filed Against Nine West 


	WHITE PLAINS, N.Y. (AP) -- A federal class-action lawsuit has  
been filed against Nine West Group and several large department 
store chains, claiming they kept prices artificially high for years 
on 12 brands of women's shoes. 


	The suit claims that Nine West enforced the price list by  
threatening to cut off supplies to any retailer who didn't toe the 
line. Violations were reported to the company by ``agents'' from 
the stores, who spied on each other. 


	``The defendants sold millions of pairs of Nine West footwear,  
at prices inflated by the illegal price-fixing conspiracy,'' 
according to the lawsuit, filed last week in White Plains, where 
Nine West is headquartered. 


	Joshua Rubin, lawyer for the plaintiffs, is asking federal Judge  
Barrington Parker to certify the lawsuit as a class action on 
behalf of anyone who bought, or considered buying, Nine West models 
that were on the alleged price-fixing lists between 1988 and the 
present. 


	It seeks unspecified damages, plus an injunction against  
price-fixing agreements. 


	Nine West is also under investigation by the Federal Trade  
Commission for price-fixing allegations. 


	``The law prohibits you from telling a retailer how to market  
his goods. You can't tell a retailer not to lower his price,'' said 
Larry Schulsinger, a partner at the retail consulting firm 
Management Ventures Inc. 


	``But manufacturers know that price-cutting hurts the value of  
brand, and they have reasons to want their brand to continue to 
command strong prices.'' 


	Calls to Nine West were referred to Chief Financial Officer Bob  
Galvin, who did not return them. 


	Nine West, which makes such popular brands as Enzo Angiolini,  
Bandolino, Easy Spirit, Calvin Klein, Westies and Pappagallo, fits 
into a niche between designer shoes and discount shoes with prices 
generally between $50 and $90. 


	It claims one-fifth of all the shoes sold to women in America.  
Its shoes are sold primarily in department stores, company-owned 
retail outlets and independent shoe stores. 


	According to the suit, Nine West's top management meets at least  
four times a year with high-ranking representatives of the 
retailers that buy their shoes. Minimum prices -- and time periods 
during which the prices will be enforced -- are agreed upon for the 
various brands and models, the suit says. 


	Afterward, it says, ``The department stores and Nine West each  
monitor the retail prices charged ... by sending agents into other 
retailers' stores.'' 


	``Each department store reports to Nine West whenever it learns  
of any violation,'' the suit says, and then the company enforces 
the restrictions ``by refusing to sell them its footwear products, 
by interfering with their advertising programs and by other 
coercive retaliatory measures.'' 


	Stores named in the suit include Federated Department Stores  
Inc., which owns Macy's and Bloomingdale's, and May Department 
Stores Co., which owns Lord & Taylor, Dillard's Inc., Dayton Hudson 
Corp. and Nordstrom Inc. 


	Federated has denied involvement in price-fixing. May declined  
comment. Dayton Hudson did not return calls for comment. Officials 
at Dillard's could not be reached. 


	Nordstrom spokeswoman Brooke White said that the department  
store will contest the suit and plays ``no part in determining what 
vendors' suggested retail prices are.''

OIL CROOKS: DANGEROUS CRIMINALS CONSPIRE BALDLY IN VIENNA 



   (To purchase this ``separate buy'' article from the New York
Times Syndicate please contact syndicate sales representative DEBRA
WEYDERT at 732-390-4480)


   (Michael Kinsley is editor of Slate.)


   &UR; BY MICHAEL KINSLEY &LR;  &QL; 
 &UR; (Distributed by New York Times Special Features) &LR;  &QL;


   The population of Redmond, Wash., is under the impression that
the U.S. government takes the principles of antitrust rather
seriously. In places like Riyadh and Moscow and Oslo and Mexico
City and Vienna -- where OPEC and other oil producers meet to set
oil prices -- the very notion of U.S. antitrust principles must be
good for a horse laugh.


   Of the major categories of behavior covered by the antitrust
laws, alleged misuse of a legally acquired monopoly (the issue in
the Microsoft case) is the murkiest area. Right and wrong are only
somewhat clearer when the issue is corporate mergers.


   On the one hand, when competitors merge it reduces competition.
On the other hand, there may be genuine efficiencies from the
combination that will benefit consumers. The one clear form of
misbehavior is price-fixing.


   When competitors get together to fix prices or limit supply, you
get the stifled competition with no compensating efficiency. The
Sherman Antitrust Act forbids ``every contract, combination ... or
conspiracy in restraint of trade among the several States or with
foreign nations.'' Price-fixing is illegal ``per se,'' meaning
there's no need to prove harm or any other complication. Violators
can and do go to prison.


   The Justice Department's big price-fixing case of the moment
involves Sotheby's and Christie's, the two big art auction houses.
The case seems to rest mainly on a suspicious pattern of one
company raising its commissions and the other following a few weeks
later. (It's not even clear what's so suspicious about this. Even
in competitive markets, rivals end up charging the same price when
they sell the same products or services.) The investigation has
been going on since 1997, and no charges have been brought, but the
heads of both firms have been forced to resign. Thank you, Uncle
Sam, for your vigilance in protecting rich art collectors from
excessive fees.


   Meanwhile, in Vienna, a price-fixing conspiracy of textbook
purity, involving a commodity that affects everyone, went on
unmolested. Strolling in and out of meetings, the conspirators
talked to reporters like coaches at halftime of a sports event. The
oil minister of the United Arab Emirates told The New York Times,
``We have not discussed all the possibilities and all the
options.''


   The Algerian oil minister says, ``I worry about a decline in
demand,'' but adds, ``If there is a consensus, we will support
it.''


   What went on in Vienna is flatly felonious behavior that is
lifting billions of dollars from the pockets of American citizens.
It may be beyond the reach of conventional antitrust enforcement,
but it is not beyond all American discipline. If these oil
ministers were bank robbers (``No, we haven't yet decided whether
to go for Chase Manhattan or Commerce Bank of Kansas City ...''),
the government would do more than send a Cabinet secretary like
Energy Secretary Bill Richardson to plead for moderation. (``Look,
why not just take out a couple of suburban branches?'')


   Under the law, it makes no difference if a price-fixing
conspiracy attempts to raise prices or lower them and whether it
succeeds or fails. Raising prices too high can be self-defeating:
You get more per barrel, but you sell fewer barrels. If OPEC lowers
prices, it does so in search of the ``sweet spot'' where long-term
revenue is maximized. There is no win-win here: The interests of
the price-fixers and the interests of consumers are directly

 Judge Orders FBI Mole at ADM to Pay 


	CHICAGO (AP) -- A federal judge has ordered an FBI mole who  
helped uncover price fixing at the food processor Archer Daniels 
Midland Co. to pay back $1.17 million in salary and benefits. 


	Aside from his role helping the investigation, Mark Whitacre is  
serving a 9-year sentence for embezzling $9 million from ADM. 


	Judge Michael McCuskey ruled on Aug. 5 that because Whitacre  
didn't faithfully perform his job with the Decatur-based company, 
ADM was entitled to the salary and benefits it paid him over a 
four-year period. The amount is part of a $6.3 million judgment. 


	Whitacre and two other senior ADM executives were sentenced last  
month in what persecutors called one of the largest antitrust 
conspiracies ever brought to court. 


	They were charged with conspiring with competitors in Japan and  
Korea to fix the $600 million world market in lysine, a 
soybean-based feed additive that promotes growth in hogs and 
poultry. 


	In 1996 the company pleaded guilty to price-fixing charges.  


	Whitacre was sentenced to 30 months in the price-fixing case.  


	Because Whitacre is in prison and has multimillion-dollar  
judgments against him, the new ruling will likely have little 
effect on him. But Whitacre's attorney said it could have an 
adverse effect on corporate whistleblowers in the future. ``It 
opens the door,'' Bill T. Walker told the Chicago Tribune in 
comments published Wednesday. 


	Whitacre, the former head of ADM's bioproducts division, set the  
FBI investigation in motion by telling top executives that Japanese 
rivals were trying to sabotage the company's lysine operation. 


	But ADM called in federal investigators, who found no trace of  
sabotage. Whitacre then told the government about a global 
price-fixing conspiracy and wore a wire as an undercover informant 
at ADM.

3 FORMER ADM EXECUTIVES ARE SENTENCED FOR PRICE FIXING  
(DW)



   CHICAGO _ Three former executives of Archer Daniels Midland Co.,
including the son of its former chairman, Dwayne Andreas, were
sentenced Friday to terms ranging from two to two and a half years
in prison for their roles in a worldwide scheme to fix prices of a
feed additive manufactured by the company.


   Michael Andreas, the former vice chairman and heir apparent at
the company, and Terrance Wilson, the retired head of its corn
processing division, were sentenced to two years and ordered to pay
the maximum fine of $350,000 each.


   A third former executive, Mark Whitacre, was sentenced to two
and a half years, but not ordered to pay a fine. Whitacre, who is
already serving nine years in prison for illegally taking millions
of dollars from Archer Daniels, was ordered to serve 20 months of
the new sentence on top of his current term.


   The sentences handed down by U.S. District Court Judge Blanche
Manning added a new twist to a series of events that has bedeviled
the case from the beginning: Whitacre, who received the longest
sentence, was also the government informant who alerted federal
investigators to the price-fixing conspiracy in 1992.


   In making her ruling, Manning determined that Whitacre was a
manager of the conspiracy, which under the federal guidelines for
sentencing would require an increase in his prison term. But she
ruled that neither Andreas nor Wilson _ who prosecutors contended
were the masterminds of the scheme _ had controlling roles. Manning
did not explain the reasons for her decision.


   The three men were convicted last September of conspiring with
Japanese and Korean competitors to fix the price of the feed
additive lysine, and to assign each company its production volume.


   Neither Andreas nor Wilson showed any reaction to the sentence.
Whitacre was sentenced by telephone. The men had faced maximum
sentences of three years in prison.

CLUES TO THE STIFF SENTENCE FOR WHISTLEBLOWER IN ARCHER DANIELS
CASE  
(DW)



   When a federal judge in Chicago handed down prison terms last
week for three former executives of Archer Daniels Midland Co. who
were convicted of fixing prices, she added a final twist to a
bizarre case: the stiffest sentence went to the informant who first
alerted the government to the crime.


   How could that be?


   In part, the outcome stems from the complex workings of the
federal sentencing guidelines, which use a complex formula for
determining ranges for prison terms for each defendant. In this
case, that formula did not work to the best interest of the
informant, Mark Whitacre.


   But it also is partly the result of one finding by Judge Blanche
Manning during the sentencing hearing that has left legal experts
perplexed. She determined that Whitacre was a manager of the
conspiracy _ and thus liable to heavier penalties _ even though he
was outranked by at least one of his co-defendants, whom she found
to have no managerial role.


   ``I don't understand how it's possible,'' said John C. Coffee
Jr., a professor at Columbia University Law School. ``I'm just
trying to think of any shred of an explanation.''


   Some legal experts said that the outcomes in the Archer Daniels
case underscored how the sentencing guidelines _ so often
criticized by judges as a straitjacket binding them to particular
outcomes _ can, in certain cases, be about as restrictive as a
sport coat.


   In the case, the judge sentenced two executives, Michael Andreas
and Terrance Wilson, to the same sentence: two years in prison and
a $350,000 fine. Andreas, the company's former vice chairman, and
Wilson, the former head of corn processing, were chief targets of
the criminal investigation almost from its opening days in 1992.


   Whitacre was sentenced to two and a half years in prison even
though, just a few months after the price-fixing conspiracy began,
he brought the matter to the attention of the government. For years
afterward, he worked as a government informant in the case,
secretly tape-recording his colleagues and competitors as they met
to fix prices.


   But Whitacre brought many of his troubles on himself. Soon after
raids on Archer Daniels in 1995, Whitacre was discredited as a
witness and eventually lost his immunity from prosecution, when it
was disclosed that he had been illegally taking millions of dollars
from the company, even while working as an informant.


   That alone helped to account for some part of the odd outcome in
the price-fixing sentence. In 1997, Whitacre pleaded guilty to
fraud charges and was already serving a nine-year sentence. As a
result, under the sentencing guideline calculations, Whitacre would
be treated as a repeat offender _ a designation that automatically
pumps up the possible sentences under the guidelines.


   Then, by ruling that Whitacre was a manager in the conspiracy,
while his co-defendants were not, the judge increased Whitacre's
``offense level'' to the highest of any of the executives.

bizarre view of the word manager,'' said Gerald Lefcourt, a
prominent defense lawyer in New York City. ``The vice chairman is
at the higher level of the conspiracy. Not to give him a managerial
role and to give it to someone who carried out the price fixing is
pretty silly.''

ruling. But they pointed out that Whitacre's lawyer did not object

CARGILL COUNTERPART

   CHICAGO _ A senior executive at the Archer Daniels Midland Co.
told government investigators that he had held secret talks with an
executive at Cargill Inc. to rig bids and prices in a huge food
additive market, according to recently released documents.


   The Archer Daniels executive, Barrie R. Cox, told federal
officials that in the early 1990s he had spoken more than a dozen
times with the Cargill executive, William M. Gruber, ``about what

acid to giant food and consumer product companies. Citric acid is
an additive used in everything from soft drinks to detergents.

were recently made public as part of a related criminal case, Cox
told investigators that he believed Gruber, formerly the head of
national sales of citric acid at Cargill, might have been acting
without the knowledge of other Cargill officials.


   Government prosecutors have said that Cargill did not take part

Reimer Corp. of Springfield, N.J., Hoffman-LaRoche Inc., a division
of Roche Holdings in Switzerland and Jungbunzlauer Inc. of Austria
_ in a much broader international conspiracy. That scheme involved
regular meetings in the early 1990s to illegally fix prices in the
citric acid market. The four companies eventually paid more than
$100 million to settle government charges of illegal price-fixing.


   The Justice Department said last week that it was not
investigating Cargill or Gruber at this time.


   The Cox statements could play a significant role in an appeal of
a class-action suit against Cargill, filed by purchasers of citric
acid who claim they were cheated by the company. Earlier this week,
lawyers for the purchasers filed a motion citing the Cox statements
as grounds for overturning a dismissal of the case for lack of
evidence.


   Cox said in interviews with federal prosecutors that between
1992 and 1995 he and Gruber worked together to rig bids on the sale
of citric acid to giant U.S. companies. The interviews were
conducted under a federal order that granted Cox immunity but did
not shield him from criminal prosecution for making false or
misleading statements.

 Vitamin Firms to Pay 1.1 Bln Dlrs to Settle 


WASHINGTON, September 7 (Xinhua) -- Six major vitamin producers
have agreed to pay more than 1.1 billion U.S. dollars to settle a
landmark price-fixing lawsuit, the largest sum ever paid in an
antitrust case, The Washington Post reported Tuesday.


The settlement would resolve allegations that the companies
orchestrated a nine-year conspiracy that led to artificially high
prices for hundreds of food and beverage companies.


The higher vitamin prices allegedly led to higher retail prices
for many food products, ranging from breakfast cereal to peanut
butter.


The Post reported that the tentative settlement of the civil
suit brought by corporate buyers of bulk vitamins will be
presented to U.S. District Judge Thomas F. Hogan in about two
weeks. The judge will then hold a hearing to determine the
settlement's fairness.


Last May, the U.S. Justice Department obtained a
750-million-dollar criminal fine from three of the vitamin
manufactures as a result of allegations that the companies
colluded to divide up markets and set wholesale vitamin prices.
Those three companies were F. Hoffman La Roche & Co., of
Switzerland, BASF AG of Germany, and Rhone-Poulenc SA of France.


The Post said that those three companies in addition to three
Japanese firms -- Eisai Co., Daiichi Pharmaceutical Co., and
Takeda Chemical Industries Ltd -- had reached the tentative civil
settlement. Together, the six companies account for about 80
percent of bulk sales of the most popular vitamins.


Under the agreement, nearly 1,000 corporate buyers of bulk
vitamins would receive more than 1 billion dollars reflecting
overcharges during the nine years. The newspaper said 50 law firms
would divide another 125 million dollars.

 Mitsubishi Charged in Conspiracy  
    By JOANN LOVIGLIO Associated Press Writer


	   PHILADELPHIA (AP) -- A federal grand jury indicted Mitsubishi Corp. and a
former executive of the world's largest producer of graphite electrodes
Wednesday, accusing them of taking part in a price-fixing conspiracy that led to
higher costs in the fastest-growing segment of the U.S. steel industry.


	   In separate indictments filed Wednesday in U.S. District Court, Mitsubishi
was charged with aiding and abetting a conspiracy to stifle competition in the
graphic electrode industry, and an executive from UCAR International Inc. was
charged with taking part in the conspiracy.


	   The five-year investigation has already garnered $300 million in criminal
fines and also led to charges against nine other companies or individuals.


	   Georges Schwengler, a former European export sales director at UCAR,
conspired in violation of the Sherman Act to eliminate competition in the
industry here and abroad from March 1992 until January 1997, according to the
indictment.


	   As a result, steelmakers paid higher prices for graphite electrodes used to
melt scrap and refine steel for a variety of business and consumer items.
Graphite electrodes are huge carbon columns that serve as the heat source for
"mini-mill" furnaces, which now account for half of U.S. steel production.


	   If convicted, Mitsubishi and Schwengler each are subject to the maximum
penalty for violating the Sherman Act -- a $10 million fine for a corporation,
and three years in jail and a $350,000 fine for an individual.


	   Total U.S. sales of graphite electrodes were more than $1.7 billion over the
course of the conspiracy, during which graphite electrode customers were hit
with significant price increases that far outpaced inflation, the government
said.


	   To date, the Justice Department's antitrust division has brought cases
against seven corporations and four executives and obtained more than $300
million in criminal fines from its ongoing investigation of price-fixing in the
graphite electrode industry.


	   "The department continues to seek out and prosecute all those who
participate in, or knowingly aid, international conspiracies that increase
prices for consumers and unfairly impede free and open competition," said
Assistant Attorney General Joel I. Klein.


	   In a statement, Mitsubishi denied the charges and said it would "vigorously
defend against those charges in court."


	   "Specifically, we deny aiding and abetting UCAR International Inc. ... or
anyone else to engage in any unlawful conduct," said the statement released by
attorneys Kekst and Co. "We look forward to presenting our case in federal
district court in Philadelphia, and to clearing our good name."


	   Formerly based in Danbury, Conn., UCAR recently moved its headquarters to
Nashville. Company spokesman Joel Hawthorne said UCAR did not want to comment on
the suit because it did not involve the company itself, which had agreed to
plead guilty in April 1998 and paid a then-record $110 million fine for the same
conspiracy.


	   Since then, SGL Carbon AG, a German corporation, was sentenced to pay a $135
million fine in the case. Two former UCAR executives have agreed to plead guilty
and serve time in prison. SGL's chief executive, Robert J. Koehler, was
sentenced to pay a $10 million fine, the largest ever imposed on an individual.
