   WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. _ It happens every spring.


   Passover comes, the price of kosher-for-Passover matzo soars in
South Florida compared with metro New York and other areas. Angry
consumers complain the fix is in.


   But an 18-month investigation by Florida Attorney General Bob
Butterworth into Passover matzo manufacturing, distributing and
retailing refutes the conspiracy theory. The report says a regional
price-fixing scheme doesn't make much sense because it would be
just as easy _ and more profitable _ to do it nationally.


   Passover matzo is the unleavened bread traditionally eaten at
the Jewish holiday to commemorate the deliverance of the ancient
Hebrews from slavery in Egypt. Seemingly every year, South Florida
grocers sell Passover matzo at prices two or three times the price
in other metropolitan areas with large Jewish populations.


   Two years ago, angry constituents contacted U.S. Rep. Robert
Wexler (D-Boca Raton), who in turn asked Butterworth to
investigate. The issue even spawned a lawsuit in Palm Beach County
Circuit Court that charged the two domestic matzo manufacturers,
Manischewitz Co. LLC and Aron Streit Inc., with collusion.


   Butterworth's report illustrated the problem this way: During
the 1997 Passover season, a 5-pound box of Manischewitz Passover
matzo sold for $11.99 at Publix supermarkets in South Florida but
sold for only $3.99 at the Ralph's grocery chain in Los Angeles.
Similar discrepancies occur ever year in New York and New Jersey.


   But the difference, according to Butterworth, can be explained
by competition. Grocery stores in other areas use Passover matzo as
a loss leader, an item sold below cost to draw customers into the
stores.


   Still, South Florida grocers say they're not making money on the
item.


   ``We're not charging more than what we pay,'' said Carmen
Millares, community affairs manager for the Miami division of
Publix. ``Actually, we're losing money.''


   Publix has Passover matzo on special, charging $9.99 for a
5-pound box.


   The conspiracy theory went nowhere in court either. In 1997,
Palm Beach County resident Sylvia Confino sued Manischewitz and
Aron Streit alleging they fixed Passover matzo prices.


   Less than four months after filing the suit, Confino withdrew
it.


   ``They convinced us that it would be exceedingly difficult for
us to show there was a conspiracy,'' said Boca Raton attorney Paul
Geller, who represented Confino.


   Said Jeffrey Weissman, a Fort Lauderdale attorney who
represented Aron Streit: ``They brought it on a wing and a prayer,
and no facts. It's closed. As far as we're concerned, it wasn't
worth opening.''


   Still, there are skeptics out there who believe something is
amiss somewhere. West Palm Beach residents Harold and Shirley
Morgenstern are among them, pointing to an ad from a New Jersey
newspaper showing matzo and other Passover fare priced well below
what the same items sell for in South Florida stores.


   ``I could see a couple of cents difference,'' Shirley
Morgenstern said. ``They have to make a profit in New Jersey just
as they do here. I really don't buy it.''

	NEW YORK (AP) -- Several big agricultural and food companies say  
they will pursue their own claims for damages and have opted out of 
a $1.1 billion proposed settlement of a price-fixing case against

	Six of the world's biggest vitamin makers are close to settling

civil case. Last May, the Justice Department won a record $725

charges they colluded to divide up markets and set wholesale 
prices.

Co., Daiichi Pharmaceutical Co. and Takeda Chemical Industries 
Ltd., all of Japan, are part of the tentative civil settlement.

believed most of the companies that would be entitled to a

Forest Laboratories, and a group of drug wholesalers.


   The suit, which had been brought by more than 40,000 pharmacies
across the United States, accused the drug makers of conspiring to
fix prices by creating a dual pricing system that gave discounts to
health-care providers and health-management organizations but not
to retail pharmacies.


   After a jury heard more than nine weeks of testimony and
depositions, however, lawyers for the defendants made a motion for
dismissal, and it was granted. Kocoras said on Monday that the
accusations made were not supported by evidence presented at the
trial.


   John Treece, a lawyer for the drug makers, said the finding was
a clear vindication of the discounting policies used by many drug
companies. Perry Goldberg, a lawyer for the pharmacies, declined to
comment.


   Lawyers for the pharmacies are expected to appeal the decision,
however, and drug manufacturers still face several other major
lawsuits. More than 5,000 pharmacies have also filed a price-fixing
suit in federal court here, and a group of chain stores have also
brought suit.


   Several of the nation's largest drug makers, including Merck and
Pfizer, were not involved in the suit here. In the last two years,
that larger group agreed to pay more than $700 million to settle
accusations that they engaged in price-fixing.

BUSINESS AT A GLANCE 



   3 EX-ARCHER EXECUTIVES CONVICTED OF FIXING PRICES


   Three former executives of Archer Daniels Midland _ including
the son of its powerful chairman, Dwayne Andreas _ were found
guilty of engaging in an international conspiracy to fix the prices
of a widely used additive for animal feed.


   The verdict by a federal jury in Chicago marked an important
victory for prosecutors and capped a six-year effort by the
government to crack an illegal cartel and to bring participants in
the conspiracy to trial. The investigation and trial have been
declared hallmarks by the government, which said it upended a
conspiracy that controlled the prices of $1 billion in commerce.


   $3.4 BILLION APPROVED FOR IMF


   The House approved only $3.4 billion of the $18 billion that
President Clinton is seeking for the International Monetary Fund.
The action left the agency in limbo as its reserves dwindle and
economic crises mount around the world. The Senate has approved the
full amount, and there is still a chance that when both houses meet
over the next few weeks to iron out their differences they will
agree to provide the full request.


   BOND YIELDS CONTINUE THEIR SLIDE


   Treasury bond prices rallied as investors sold stocks and sought
the safety of government securities. The yield on the 30-year bond
dropped to 5.18 percent, from 5.22 percent on Wednesday, its lowest
level in 30 years. In the last three months the 30-year bond's
yield has fallen more than half a percentage point.


   BAYER TO ACQUIRE UNIT OF CHIRON


   Bayer, the German drug and chemical giant, will buy the American
diagnostics business of Chiron for $1.1 billion and 50 percent of
the farm seed subsidiary of Crompton & Knowles. Bayer also said it
would raise money for reorganization by selling to the public up to
75 percent of its Agfa-Gevaert unit.


   AMENDMENT SLOWS SPENDING BILL


   A proposal to make it easier for farmers to hire foreigners,
most from Mexico, at harvest time is clouding prospects for
congressional approval of a spending bill for the Commerce, Justice
and State Departments.


   HOUSE PANEL PASSES TAX CUT BILL


   The House Ways and Means Committee passed an $80 billion
Republican tax cut, setting up a confrontation with President
Clinton.


   BANKS MORE EXPOSED TO LOAN RISK


   Banks are exposing themselves to increased levels of financial
risk as 1998 loan underwriting standards declined for the fourth
consecutive year, according to an annual survey by the Office of
the Comptroller of the Currency.


   TRADE DEFICIT GREW 2% IN JULY


   The trade deficit widened 2 percent in July as exports fell for
the fourth consecutive month, while consumer prices changed little
in August, Government figures showed. Those findings, together with
two other reports that showed a decline in jobless claims and a
rise in workers' incomes, suggested that the economy was holding up
well in its eighth year of expansion, analysts said.


   NIKE PROFIT DROPS 35% IN QUARTER


   Nike, the world's top seller of athletic footwear, said its
profit dropped 35 percent in the first quarter because of sluggish
sales in Asia.

   Two San Francisco securities firms, Hambrecht & Quist and
BancBoston Robertson Stephens, are targets of a federal probe into
possible fixing of fees in initial public stock offerings,
according to people familiar with the situation.


   The Justice Department this week sent the two investment banks
formal demands to produce information on how they set the fees for
taking companies public, the sources said.


   The inquiries are part of a larger Justice investigation into
possible illegal price fixing in IPOs that reportedly is targeting
most of the nation's large securities firms, including Goldman
Sachs, Salomon Smith Barney and Lehman Brothers.


   The probe came to light yesterday when Goldman Sachs disclosed
in a regulatory filing that it had received a Justice Department
subpoena as part of an ``investigation of an alleged conspiracy
among securities underwriters to fix underwriting fees.''


   Justice ``is looking at the possibility of anticompetitive
practices in underwriting services for IPOs,'' said department
spokeswoman Gina Talamona, who declined to elaborate.


   Representatives of Hambrecht & Quist and Robertson Stephens
declined to comment on the probe.


   The two firms were respectively the nation's 12th and 13th
largest IPO managers in the first quarter of 1999, according to
Securities Data Corp. Hambrecht & Quist led or co-managed 14
transactions worth $299.4 million, while Robertson Stephens did the
same in 11 IPOs worth $238 million.


   Justice's investigation won't necessarily result in federal
legal action and fines against the firms, antitrust experts noted.


   ``The threshold for starting an investigation has gotten fairly
low,'' said Washington, D.C., antitrust lawyer Joe Sims, who
estimated that only 25 to 30 percent of such probes result in
further enforcement measures.


   The federal investigation follows several private lawsuits
brought by law firms that specialize in class-action securities
litigation.


   These suits accuse 25 securities firms, including Hambrecht &
Quist and Robertson Stephens, of conspiring to keep IPO fees
artificially high, raising costs to investors and companies selling
stock to the public. The suits were recently combined into a single
class-action case in a New York federal court.


   The complaint in the case says that securities firms charged
clients a fee of exactly 7 percent in 95 percent of midsize IPOs
from 1995 to 1997. Such a set fee could only hold if the firms
colluded to keep the price at that level, the complaint maintains.


   ``We're alleging that from 1994 to the present, these
underwriters fixed the fees,'' said Alice McInerney, a New York
attorney representing plaintiffs in the case.


   &LR;   &LR;  McInerney said conspiracy charges are based on a statistical
analysis of fees, and that she had no evidence of communications
among investment bankers to fix prices.


   &LR;   &LR;  McInerney declined to comment on whether she's talked with
Justice antitrust officials about the case. But it's common in such
cases for attorneys to pass on their findings to federal
regulators.


   The plaintiffs' case is based partly on academic research by two
University of Florida business school professors who published a
study noting that midsize IPO fees cluster around 7 percent, a
level they said was more than twice as high as fees charged in the
past.

 Judge Refuses $25M ADM Penalties 


	CHICAGO (AP) -- Rebuking government prosecutors for a ``wholly  
deceptive'' argument, a federal judge ruled that two former Archer 
Daniels Midland Co. executives convicted of price-fixing will 
receive fines of no more than $350,000. 


	The fines will be far less than the $25 million the government  
had sought. 


	Michael Andreas, on leave as ADM executive vice president, and  
Terrance Wilson, former head of the corn division, will be 
sentenced July 9 in a scheme to set high prices for the cattle feed 
additive known as lysine. Andreas, son of longtime ADM chief Dwayne 
Andreas, and Wilson were convicted last September. 


	In seeking the $25 million fines, as well as prison time for  
Andreas, prosecutors said such punishment would reflect the amount 
of money ADM allegedly reaped in the scheme. 


	But U.S. District Judge Blanche Manning berated the Justice  
Department in a ruling Wednesday, saying it failed to prove how 
much lysine sales were affected by the scheme. 


	The defendants had said a $25 million fine was too high, given  
the amount of lysine produced in the world during the price-fixing 
scheme. They sought proof for their argument from overseas lysine 
producers who allegedly participated in the price-fixing 
conspiracy. 


	Manning said the government wrote letters to the overseas  
producers ``informing them that they were not obliged to produce 
documents'' for Andreas and Wilson. She called the government's 
action ``so incredible that it bordered on being ludicrous.'' 


	She also called the government's defense of the action ``wholly  
deceptive.'' Prosecutors had claimed that it was unclear whether 
foreign businesses could be required to cooperate with the U.S. 
justice system. 


	In addition to the fine, federal prosecutors had sought three  
years in prison, the maximum allowable, against Andreas. Manning 
did not address prison time in her ruling. 


	A Justice Department spokeswoman would not comment on strategy  
following Manning's order. 


	``We are disappointed with the judge's decision and we are  
prepared for the sentencing on July 9,'' spokeswoman Jennifer Rose 
said. 


	Mark Whitacre, the mole who tape-recorded meetings where the  
price-fixing scheme was discussed, will also be sentenced July 9. 
His attorney is seeking a sentence concurrent with the nine-year 
term Whitacre is already serving for bilking ADM of $9 million 
while working as chief of the bioproducts division. Manning said he 
also faces a maximum $350,000 fine.

   BIG VITAMIN MAKERS AGREE TO SETTLE PRICE-FIXING SUIT


   Six of the world's largest vitamin makers have agreed to pay
about $1.1 billion to resolve a class-action lawsuit that accused

   The settlement, which could come this week, would be one of the
largest antitrust payments made in a private class-action suit in
U.S. history, lawyers said.

   Expanding the reach of advanced fiber optic communications in
Asia, Microsoft, Global Crossing of Bermuda and Softbank of Japan
have agreed to form a $1.3 billion joint venture to build a fiber
optic communications web stretching from Japan to Malaysia,
executives close to the agreement said. The companies intend to
announce the venture, to be called Asia Global Crossing, as soon as
Wednesday. Shares of Microsoft fell $1.625, to $94.25, while Global
Crossing fell $2.0625, to $20.3125.

   A failure to quell the chaos in East Timor could strangle
Indonesia's fragile economic recovery, analysts and government
officials said. Officials fear that foreign lenders will shun
Indonesia while local business will lose confidence in the
government.


   STOCKS RETREAT ON RATE WORRIES

investors feared rising commodity prices might lead the Federal
Reserve to raise interest rates again. The Dow Jones industrial
average lost 44.32 points, to 11,034.13. The Standard & Poor's
500-stock index fell 6.79 points, to 1,350.45, and the Nasdaq
composite index dropped 5.85 points, to 2,837.26.

report on producer prices and speeches by Federal Reserve
officials. The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.07 percent from
6.01 percent on Friday.

network computing business Wednesday with an ultra-stripped down
computing ``appliance'' for corporate customers.

sixth-largest bank, have sued the company, contending it put its
profits ahead of its employees' best interests in managing their
in-house 401(k) retirement plans.

   Liberty Media Group, AT&T's cable-television programming
company, agreed to buy a stake in Europe's No. 2 cable company,
United Pan-Europe Communications, for $493 million in cash.
Liberty, which is led by John C. Malone, is forming a venture with
Microsoft and United Pan-Europe to cooperate on buying other cable
companies and developing programs and technology.


   KNOWLEDGE OF INQUIRY DISCLOSED

Russian money laundering at the Bank of New York as long ago as
March, not just last month, officials said.

stock exchanges to attract more investors.

   BP Amoco and other foreign creditors said that they had accepted
an offer by Russia to resolve the bankruptcy of the oil company
Sidanko, a move that could bolster BP Amoco's yearlong effort to
preserve its $571 million investment in the company.

software business as an entrepreneurial hotbed, fast-changing and

also-ran, he said.


   SPORT UTILITY BUMPERS CALLED WEAK


   The bumpers on sport utility vehicles tend to be weak, allowing
more damage to occur in low-speed collisions than bumpers on cars,
an insurance industry group said.


   SAN FRANCISCO PAPER UP FOR SALE

sale of all or some of the company, which includes The San
Francisco Chronicle, one of the last family-owned newspapers in the
country.

SHERMAN ANTITRUST ACT DATES TO 1890  
(DW) 



   The Sherman Antitrust Act, passed in 1890, outlaws all
contracts, combinations and conspiracies that unreasonably restrain
interstate trade. Common examples are price fixing and bid rigging.


   The act also makes it a crime to monopolize any part of
interstate commerce. An unlawful violation occurs when a company
dominates or attempts to dominate the market for a product or
service, but only if it has sought, achieved or maintained that
dominance by suppressing competition with anti-competitive conduct.


   Sherman Act violations can be prosecuted as felonies or
litigated in civil suits, as in the case the Justice Department and
19 states brought against Microsoft.

 Ex-Drug Co. Exec To Plead Guilty 


	WASHINGTON (AP) -- A former Swiss pharmaceutical company  
executive agreed Thursday to plead guilty and serve six months in 
jail for his role in a worldwide case of vitamin price-fixing, the 
Justice Department announced. 


	This was the 10th prosecution in the case in which the company,  
F. Hoffmann-La Roche, already has been sentenced to pay a record 
$500 million criminal fine. 


	Hoffmann-La Roche and some of its competitors have admitted that  
from January 1990 until this May, they raised and fixed prices and 
allocated market shares for vitamins used in virtually every 
American home and added to bread, milk and breakfast cereal. 


	In a one-count criminal charge filed in U.S. District Court in  
Dallas, the government alleged that Dr. Roland Bronnimann, a Swiss 
citizen and resident and former president of Hoffmann-La Roche's 
vitamins and fine chemicals division, conspired in violation of the 
Sherman Act to fix prices in the United States and elsewhere for 
vitamins A, B2, B5, C, E, and beta carotene. 


	In addition to the jail time, Bronnimann agreed to pay a  
$150,000 fine. 


	The government also charged that the conspirators rigged bids  
and allocated customer contracts between themselves for vitamin 
premixes throughout this country. Vitamin premixes are used to 
enrich breakfast cereals and numerous other processed foods. 


	``Bronnimann knew of, approved and participated in key aspects  
of Hoffmann-La Roche's operation in the vitamins cartel,'' said 
Gary R. Spratling, deputy assistant attorney general in charge of 
antitrust criminal enforcement. 


	``As a member of Hoffmann-La Roche's executive committee at the  
time of his involvement, Bronnimann put the full weight of 
legitimacy behind the company's involvement in the most pervasive 
international cartel ever uncovered.'' 


	The government said Bronnimann conspired with counterparts at  
BASF, Rhone-Poulenc and other unnamed competitors. 


	Bronnimann is the second former senior Hoffmann-La Roche  
executive to be charged in the continuing investigation. On May 20, 
Dr. Kuno Sommer, former director of worldwide marketing for 
Hoffmann-La Roche's vitamins and fine chemicals division, was 
charged with participating in the vitamin cartel and with lying to 
Justice Department investigators in 1997 to cover up the 
conspiracy. 


	Sommer, also a Swiss citizen and resident, pleaded guilty and  
was sentenced July 23 to four months in prison and fined $100,000. 


	On March 2, a third foreign national, Antonio Felix, a Mexican  
citizen and vice president for basic and international products at 
DuCoa L.P., agreed to plead guilty to plotting to fix the prices of 
vitamin B4. He has not been sentenced.

in the case.

 Wholesalers Sue Tobacco Industry  
    By LAURIE ASSEO Associated Press Writer


	   WASHINGTON (AP) -- A federal lawsuit targeted the tobacco industry anew
Tuesday, accusing it of carrying out a "long-running and systematic" plan to fix
cigarette prices charged to wholesalers.


	   The lawsuit, filed in U.S. District Court,asserts that the major U.S.
cigarette manufacturers met secretly to make illegal agreements on wholesale
prices.


	   Filed by two cigarette wholesalers, in Buffalo, N.Y., and Bryan, Texas, the
lawsuit seeks triple damages and class-action status to represent all
wholesalers hurt by the alleged price-fixing.


	   The tobacco industry has been under mounting pressure for selling a product
the American Cancer Society calls the leading cause of cancer. All 50 states
reached settlements in which tobacco companies will pay them $246 billion for
the cost of treating smoking-related illnesses.


	   The Justice Department also sued the industry last September, seeking
additional billions of dollars to repay federal health-insurance costs. And, a
Florida jury ruled in a class-action lawsuit last July that the cigarette makers
produced a defective and deadly product. That jury is now considering damages
that industry lawyers say could exceed $300 billion.


	   The lawsuit filed Tuesday alleges the major tobacco companies fixed prices
during meetings of cigarette company lawyers who "frequently discussed, and
reached agreements regarding, future price increases for cigarettes."


	   Daniel W. Donahue, deputy general counsel for R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co., one
of the defendants, said the lawsuit "is totally without any basis in fact or
law, and we certainly intend to defend the case."


	   Donahue said the issues of price increases and competitive practices "were
always avoided" at the meetings of industry lawyers.


	   Michael York, an attorney for Philip Morris, said the lawsuit was "so
meritless on its face the only conclusion one can draw is that it's simply a
maneuver by lawyers for more fees."


	   Those named defendant include Philip Morris Cos.; R.J. Reynolds Tobacco
Holdings Inc.; Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corp., a unit of British American
Tobacco Co., Ltd.; Lorillard Tobacco Co., a unit of Loews Corp.; and Liggett
Group, a unit of Brooke Group Ltd.


	   The lawsuit said there was virtually no cigarette price competition from the
1950s until 1980, when Liggett introduced low-price "generic discount"
cigarettes.


	   Other companies introduced generic brands, and after a 1993 price war, a
price increase announced by Philip Morris signaled to the other companies "that

 Wholesalers Sue Tobacco Industry  
    By LAURIE ASSEO Associated Press Writer


	   WASHINGTON (AP) -- A federal lawsuit targeted the tobacco industry anew
Tuesday, accusing it of carrying out a "long-running and systematic" plan to fix
cigarette prices charged to wholesalers.


	   The lawsuit, filed in U.S. District Court, asserts that the major U.S.

reached settlements in which tobacco companies will pay them $246 billion for
the cost of treating smoking-related illnesses.


	   The Justice Department also sued the industry last September, seeking
additional billions of dollars to repay federal health-insurance costs. And, a
Florida jury ruled in a class-action lawsuit last July that the cigarette makers
produced a defective and deadly product. That jury is now considering damages
that industry lawyers say could exceed $300 billion.


	   The lawsuit filed Tuesday alleges the major tobacco companies fixed prices
during meetings of cigarette company lawyers who "frequently discussed, and
reached agreements regarding, future price increases for cigarettes."


	   Daniel W. Donahue, deputy general counsel for R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co., one
of the defendants, said the lawsuit "is totally without any basis in fact or
law, and we certainly intend to defend the case."

DRUG MAKERS TENTATIVELY SETTLE IN PRICE-FIXING SUIT 



   In one of the United States' bitterest scuffles over fair trade,
four pharmaceutical companies have tentatively agreed to pay $345
million to settle a class-action price-fixing lawsuit brought by
40,000 retail pharmacies, according to lawyers involved in the
case.

Hoechst Marion Roussel unit of Hoechst AG of Germany and
Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. appeared Tuesday before U.S. District
Judge Charles Kocoras in Chicago to present the proposed
settlement. Details of the agreement were not fully disclosed.

filed in 1993, and eventually consolidated into one class-action
case, that large drug makers had conspired to develop a two-tier
pricing system during the early 1990s. The drug makers gave
discounts to managed-care companies and health-maintenance
organizations, the pharmacy owners said, while charging them higher
prices.


   Under the deal presented Tuesday, the drug makers agreed to
refrain from a two-tier pricing system, without admitting any
liability, said lawyers involved in the agreement.


   While Tuesday's proposed settlement moved the case one step
closer to completion, it remains far from over.


   Two years ago, 11 pharmaceutical makers agreed to pay $351
million to settle the price-fixing contentions, leaving eight
defendants in the case. After four more agreed to the proposed
settlement Tuesday, that left four big pharmaceutical companies _
Novartis, Johnson & Johnson, the G.D. Searle unit of Monsanto and
Forest Laboratories _ to refute the pharmacies' contentions in a
trial before Kocoras, which is set to begin Sept. 14.


   ``We are encouraged four drug manufacturers are joining others
who have previously agreed to settle a class-action lawsuit by
retail community pharmacies over allegations of manufacturer
price-fixing,'' said Ronald L. Ziegler, the chief executive of the
National Association of Chain Drug Stores, an industry group in
Alexandria, Va. ``Hopefully, all manufacturers will practice the
terms of the settlement.''

comment Tuesday. Pharmacia & Upjohn said in a statement that it had
agreed to pay $102.5 million, a bit less than one-third of the
total tentative settlement. As a result, the company said, it must
increase reserves by $61 million and take a $41 million after-tax
charge against earnings in the second quarter, which ended June 30.

that the amount the company had agreed to pay was ``substantially
less'' than Pharmacia & Upjohn's share. Rhone-Poulenc agreed to
settle, he said, to avoid the risks and uncertainty of litigation.

amount to about $700 million, which will be held in escrow until
the case is completed. The pharmacy owners must determine how the
money will be divided. Initially, the small pharmacy owners had
wanted an equal split regardless of size, while proprietors of the
larger stores wanted a formula based on per-store drug sales
volume.

special attention will be given to the sales of books over the
Internet, the Commission added.

 Gas Station Owners Sue Oil Cos. 


	LOS ANGELES (AP) -- Three major gasoline companies are trying to  
push independent service stations out of business by conspiring to 
fix prices, according to a lawsuit filed by a group of California 
station owners. 


	The antitrust suit filed Tuesday in U.S. District Court contends  
Shell Oil Co., Texaco Inc. and Saudi Refining Inc. have tried to 
use joint marketing agreements to fix prices while raising rents 
and the wholesale price dealers must pay for gasoline. 


	The goal, the owners contend, is to replace small independents  
with bigger company-owned stations. 


	Company representatives said the allegations were false.  


	The lawsuit alleges that prices have been fixed since 1996  
through joint refining and marketing ventures established by the 
companies. It seeks unspecified damages and to have the joint 
ventures dissolved. 


	``It's a straight, old-fashioned price-fixing agreement,'' said  
Joseph Alioto, the attorney for 39 dealers named as plaintiffs in 
the suit. 


	During the past 18 months, the prices dealers have paid for gas  
have risen between 25 cents and 55 cents per gallon, said Tom 
Bleau, co-counsel for the 39 dealers named as plaintiffs in the 
suit. Over the same period, the price in the gasoline futures 
market has declined by more than 4 cents a gallon. 


	Rent increases have ranged from 30 percent to 100 percent, Bleau  
said. An independent dealer rents a gas station location from an 
oil company, but owns the business itself. 


	The three companies refine and market gasoline in the eastern  
United States through Houston-based Motiva Enterprises LLC. 


	Texaco and Shell refine and market in the West and Midwest  
through a separate firm, Equilon Enterprises LLC, also based in 
Houston. Saudi Refining is not part of Equilon. 


	A third company, Equiva Services, provides various services to  
Motiva and Equilon. The three ventures also were named in the 
lawsuit. 


	``The formation of Equilon, Motiva and Equiva was done for  
legitimate business reasons,'' said Andy Norman, a spokesman for 
Texaco. ``It was totally proper and the formation of those 
companies has led to a number of efficiencies in our ... 
operations.'' 


	Creation of the ventures was the subject of an investigation by  
the Federal Trade Commission and attorney generals in several 
states where the companies operate. No wrongdoing was found, Norman 
said. 


	Equilon issued a statement calling the allegations preposterous.  
Calls to the other defendants were not immediately returned. 


	In the suit, dealers contend their rents and prices were raised  
soon after the joint ventures began. As a result, they have had to 
sell gasoline at uncompetitive prices, they said. 


	Small stations, whether independent or company owned, have  
struggled to sell enough gasoline to stay open, but ``these are 
market forces. They're not collusion,'' said Bill Berman, publisher 
of The Pump Price Report, a weekly survey of gasoline prices and 
supply. 


	``They're not intentional efforts by the refiners or  
wholesalers,'' he said. 


	The gas station business has grown increasingly difficult in  
recent years. The number of service stations in the United States 
has dropped sharply during the past five years, from 202,800 to 
177,800, according to a survey by National Petroleum News, a trade 
magazine. The survey did not include separate numbers for 
independent dealers.

 Nine West to pay $34 million to settle price-fixing charges  
By KALPANA SRINIVASAN, Associated Press Writer


   WASHINGTON (AP) -- Nine West Group Inc., one of the nation's
largest suppliers of women's shoes, settled a price-fixing case
Monday by agreeing to pay states $34 million and stop dictating
what stores charge for its footwear.


   The Federal Trade Commission and attorneys general in 56 U.S.
states and territories had alleged that the company violated
antitrust laws stipulating when retailers could offer shoes at
reduced prices and distributing lists of shoes that could not be
discounted.


   New Jersey's share was more than $880,000.


   Nine West sells shoes under such brand names as Nine West,
Amalfi, Bandolino, 9 & Co., Calico, Easy Spirit, Evan-Picone,
Pappagallo, Capezio, Calvin Klein, Selby, and Enzo Angiolini.


   The settlement ''sends a strong signal to companies that fixing
resale prices violates the law and will result in enforcement
actions,'' said Richard G. Parker, director of the FTC's Bureau of
Competition.


   Retailers who did not adhere to Nine West policies were
threatened with cancellations, denied orders or were not given
discounts, officials said.


   As a result, competition among retailers selling Nine West
brands was restricted and the price of the company's shoes were
kept artificially high, the FTC's complaint said.


   Officials with Nine West, based in White Plains, N.Y., said the
settlement was not an admission of liability.


   ''We believe that this was the most efficient manner in which to
resolve this issue, avoiding substantial legal expense and
management time,'' said Jacki Nemerov, president of Jones Apparel
Group, which acquired Nine West last summer. The alleged price
fixing occurred from January 1988 to July 1999.


   The company entered into two separate settlements, one with the
attorneys general of the 50 states, the District of Columbia,
Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, American Samoa, Northern Mariana
Islands and Guam. The other is with the FTC.


   The FTC settlement prohibits Nine West from setting the price at
which retailers can advertise, promote or sell shoes or coercing
retailers to stick to any one price. The company also cannot notify
dealers in advance that they are subject to suspension if they sell
Nine West shoes below a designated price. Nine West must also
notify its dealers that they have the right to set the price for
the company's products.


   The agreement with the states requires a payment of $34 million.
Of this, no more than $3.5 million will cover attorney's fees,
while the rest will be used to fund women's health, educational,
vocational and safety programs.


   The settlement was filed in U.S. District Court in New York
immediately after a lawsuit was filed against Nine West in the same
court. The agreement resolves the suit, but gives the court
jurisdiction over the terms of the settlement.


   ''When even one business won't play by the rules and illegally
overcharges its customers, everybody gets hurts,'' said South
Carolina Attorney General Charlie Condon. He is proposing that the
state use its portion of the money to assist rape victims and
crisis pregnancy centers.

 Former ADM Executives Sentenced 


	CHICAGO (AP) -- Three senior executives of food-processing giant  
Archer Daniels Midland Co. have been sentenced to multiyear prison 
terms in a price-fixing case prosecutors called one of the largest 
antitrust conspiracies ever brought to court. 


	Michael Andreas, 51, whose father Dwayne Andreas built ADM into  
a global agribusiness, was sentenced Friday to two years in prison 
along with 60-year-old Terrance Wilson, the retired head of ADM's 
corn division. 


	They also were fined $350,000 by U.S. District Judge Blanche  
Manning for conspiring with competitors in Japan and Korea to fix 
the $600 million world market in lysine, a feed additive that 
promotes growth in hogs and poultry. They were convicted in 
September. 


	Mark Whitacre, 49, former head of ADM's bioproducts division,  
was sentenced to 30 months -- 20 of that to be served on top of a 
nine-year sentence he is currently serving for swindling ADM out of 
$9 million. 


	Whitacre, who wore a wire as an undercover FBI informant at ADM  
but later fell out with the government, heard his sentence from a 
federal prison camp in Edgefield, S.C. He waived his right to be in 
court. 


	``Life in prison is actually better than life at ADM,'' the  
Ohio-born biochemist told the court. He bitterly denounced not only 
the company but the FBI, saying, ``I risked my life and my career'' 
to help them. 


	As part of his sentence, Manning directed Whitacre to seek  
mental health treatment once he is released from prison. His 
attorney, Bill Walker, says that he has bipolar disease and is on 
medication. 


	Andreas apologized to the court but stopped short of admitting  
any wrongdoing. Andreas' and Wilson's attorneys said they would 
appeal. 


	``I love this country, your honor, and I thought I knew its  
rules,'' Andreas told Manning before he was sentenced. ``I did not 
want to commit a crime, and I did not think that I had committed a 
crime.'' 


	Prosecutors said the sentences should serve as a deterrent to  
any would-be price fixers. 


	``It's not the longest sentence ever imposed but it's a long  
sentence under the antitrust guidelines,'' said Justice Department 
lawyer James Griffin. 


	ADM, based in Decatur, deep in central Illinois' corn and  
soybean country, has paid a $100 million fine and settled three 
antitrust lawsuits for an additional $90 million. 


	Andreas and Wilson are to report to prison in September.

 Nine West Settles Charges for $34M  
By KALPANA SRINIVASAN, Associated Press Writer


   WASHINGTON (AP) -- Nine West Group Inc., one of the nation's
largest suppliers of women's shoes, settled a price-fixing case
Monday by agreeing to pay states $34 million and stop dictating
what stores charge for its footwear.


   The Federal Trade Commission and attorneys general in 56 U.S.
states and territories had alleged that the company violated
antitrust laws stipulating when retailers could offer shoes at
reduced prices and distributing lists of shoes that could not be
discounted.


   Nine West sells shoes under such brand names as Nine West,
Amalfi, Bandolino, 9 & Co., Calico, Easy Spirit, Evan-Picone,
Pappagallo, Capezio, Calvin Klein, Selby, and Enzo Angiolini.


   The settlement ''sends a strong signal to companies that fixing
resale prices violates the law and will result in enforcement
actions,'' said Richard G. Parker, director of the FTC's Bureau of
Competition.


   Retailers who did not adhere to Nine West policies were
threatened with cancellations, denied orders or were not given
discounts, officials said.


   As a result, competition among retailers selling Nine West
brands was restricted and the price of the company's shoes were
kept artificially high, the FTC's complaint said.


   Officials with Nine West, based in White Plains, N.Y., said the
settlement was not an admission of liability.


   ''We believe that this was the most efficient manner in which to
resolve this issue, avoiding substantial legal expense and
management time,'' said Jacki Nemerov, president of Jones Apparel
Group, which acquired Nine West last summer. The alleged price
fixing occurred between January 1998 and July 1999.


   The company entered into two separate settlements, one with the
attorneys general of the 50 states, the District of Columbia,
Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, American Samoa, Northern Mariana
Islands and Guam. The other is with the FTC.


   The FTC settlement prohibits Nine West from setting the price at
which retailers can advertise, promote or sell shoes or coercing
retailers to stick to any one price. The company also cannot notify
dealers in advance that they are subject to suspension if they sell
Nine West shoes below a designated price. Nine West must also
notify its dealers that they have the right to set the price for
the company's products.


   The agreement with the states requires a payment of $34 million.
Of this, no more than $3.5 million will cover attorney's fees,
while the rest will be used to fund women's health, educational,
vocational and safety programs.


   The settlement was filed in U.S. District Court in New York
immediately after a lawsuit was filed against Nine West in the same
court. The agreement resolves the suit, but gives the court
jurisdiction over the terms of the settlement.


   ''When even one business won't play by the rules and illegally
overcharges its customers, everybody gets hurts,'' said South
Carolina Attorney General Charlie Condon. He is proposing that the
state use its portion of the money to assist rape victims and
crisis pregnancy centers.

NINE WEST AGREES TO PAY $34 MILLION FOR FIXING SHOE PRICES  
(DW)



   NEW YORK _ Nine West Group, the maker of women's shoes, agreed
Monday to pay $34 million to settle civil charges brought by
federal and state investigators who contended the company had
illegally fixed shoe prices since 1988.


   Government officials said they will divide the $34 million
settlement among the 50 states and other U.S. territories to be
used to fund women's health, educational or safety programs. The
agreement must still be approved by the Federal Trade Commission as
well as by the federal court for the Southern District of New York.


   Nine West, which was purchased by Jones Apparel Group last year,
also agreed to end its shoe pricing practices that the federal and
state governments contended were illegal. The company's practices
forced women to pay artificially high prices, the governments said,
by ending competition between stores.


   The company agreed to settle the case without admitting
wrongdoing. In a written statement, Jacki Nemerov, president of
Jones Apparel, said, ``We believe that this settlement was clearly
in the best interest of our company, avoiding substantial legal
expense and management time.''


   But the company's legal troubles are not over. Jones Apparel
still faces a class-action lawsuit filed on behalf of the millions
of women who have purchased Nine West brands, which include Easy
Spirit, Enzo Angiolini, 9 & Co., Bandolino, Evan-Picone, Amalfi,
Calico, Pappagallo, Capezio, Calvin Klein, Selby, Joyce and
Westies.


   Nine West sells about one out of every five pairs of shoes sold
to women in the United States. Most of those shoes are sold either
at the company's own retail stores or at department stores,
including Macy's, Bloomingdale's, Bon Marche, Lord & Taylor,
Marshall Fields, Dillard's and Nordstrom.


   In their complaint, federal and state investigators said that
Nine West had entered into agreements with the department stores
and other retailers to sell shoes at set prices. Nine West demanded
that the stores discount the shoes only on certain dates that the
stores and Nine West had agreed to.


   Nine West employees monitored the stores to ensure they
complied, the government said. Nine West warned the stores, the
government said, that if they did not follow the pricing rules, it
would stop shipping shoes or would not pay amounts it had promised
the stores in discounts or for advertising.


   The pricing system meant that for years, no matter how many
stores women shopped in, they would find the same prices for many
Nine West styles.


   Recent court cases have weakened federal antitrust laws so that
companies can do more to control prices and consumers are less
protected. Under the law, a company can legally tell retailers what
prices to charge and even stop shipping goods to stores that do not
comply.


   But Nine West went beyond what was legal, the government
contended, by seeking agreements from the stores on future shoe
prices and on the limited dates when the shoes could be sold at a
discount.


   The government contended the illegal activities occurred before
Jones Apparel acquired on June 15, 1999.


   The settlement requires Nine West to send a letter to all of its
retail outlets explaining the investigation, and stating that while
Nine West can suggest retail prices, the stores are free to sell
and advertise the shoes at any price they choose.


   Four states _ New York, Texas, Florida and Ohio _ took a lead in
the investigation with the Federal Trade Commission.


   New York will get $2 million of the settlement. Eliot L.
Spitzer, New York's attorney general, said Monday that the amount
will go to battered women's shelters, breast and ovarian cancer
research and preventive health programs such as mammography
screening.


   ``This sends a warning to all manufacturers,'' Spitzer said,
``that we will not tolerate illegal pricing agreements.''

 Two Former ADM Execs Sent to Jail 


	DECATUR, Ill. (AP) -- With the rejection of their latest appeals,  
two former executives of Archer Daniels Midland Co. have been 
ordered to report to federal prisons. 


	Michael D. Andreas, 50, and Terrance S. Wilson, 61, were  
convicted last year of fixing prices and were scheduled to report 
to their respective prisons today to begin serving their two-year 
sentences. 


	Andreas was originally directed to report to Greenville, Ill.,  
less than 100 miles southeast of Decatur, while Wilson was assigned 
to a prison in Oxford, Wis. 


	Those locations were recommended by a federal judge, but the  
men's final destinations will not be made public by the Federal 
Bureau of Prisons until each man has reported. 


	Scott Wilson, a spokesman for the Bureau of Prisons in  
Washington, D.C., said the odds are that Greenville and Oxford are 
the final locations. 


	``A judge's recommendation may or may not be followed. It  
usually is, but I can count thousands of cases where there has been 
a change,'' Wilson said. 


	Attorneys for both men had filed numerous motions and appeals  
that delayed the eventual prison time since their convictions by a 
federal jury in August 1998. Their last effort, filed jointly, was 
denied by the U.S. Court of Appeals Seventh Circuit on Sept. 23. 


	Andreas is on leave as ADM's executive vice president. Wilson,  
who is retired, was the head of ADM's corn division. 


	U.S. District Judge Blanche M. Manning sentenced Andreas and  
Wilson, along with FBI informer Mark E. Whitacre, on July 9. 
Whitacre, the former head of ADM's BioProducts Division, is already 
in prison on a previous conviction of embezzling $9 million from 
the company. 


	Andreas, Wilson and Whitacre were convicted in one of the  
nation's biggest federal antitrust cases ever. The government said 
they had led ADM into a global conspiracy to set prices and divide 
up competition in sales of citric acid and lysine, which is a 
protein component of hog and chicken feed.

 Three Foreign Companies Fined in U.S. for Monopoly 


WASHINGTON, August 27 (Xinhua) -- Two Japanese companies and
the New Jersey subsidiary of a Korean company agreed today to
plead guilty to conspiring to fix worldwide prices for an animal
feed additive, according to an AP report.


The three companies and their executives also agreed to pay 20
million dollars in fines for the price-fixing.


The guilty plea agreements were the first charges in the U.S.
Justice Department's investigation of price-fixing in the food and
feed additive business, which also has targeted the giant American
food processing company, Archer Daniels Midland (ADM).


No charges were filed against ADM yet. But the U.S. government
said its investigation was continuing against companies it would
not name.


"All of the corporate and individual defendants already have
begun to cooperate with the government's ongoing investigation,"
said U.S. Deputy Assistant Attorney General Gary R. Spratling,
head of the antitrust division's criminal enforcement.


The case involved lysine, an amino acid used to ensure proper
growth of swine and poultry and a 600 million dollars industry in
itself.


A criminal felony case was filed in U.S. District Court in
Chicago today charging that the six defendants conspired among
themselves and with unnamed others to suppress and eliminate
competition in the lysine market from June 1992 through June 27,
1995. It charged a violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act.


Those charged were Ajinomoto Co. Inc. of Tokyo and its former
general manager of the feed additives division, Kyowa Hakko Kogyo
Co. Ltd. of Tokyo and its former general manager of the
agricultural products department and Sewon America Inc., N.J., and
its president. Sewon America is a subsidiary of Sewon Company Ltd.
of Seoul, South Korea.

BUSINESS AT A GLANCE



   LARGE SETTLEMENT EXPECTED IN VITAMIN PRICE-FIXING CASE


   The Justice Department is expected to announce as early as
Thursday that at least two of the world's largest drug and chemical
companies have agreed to pay as much as $700 million to settle
charges that they participated in a global conspiracy to fix prices
in the sale of vitamins, people close to the talks said.


   In what would be the largest settlement ever in a federal
antitrust case, Roche Holding of Switzerland is expected to pay as
much as $500 million and BASF of Germany is expected to pay about
$200 million.


   U.S. CASE AGAINST BROKERS FALTERS


   The federal government's case against a group of stockbrokers
charged with illegal trading on the floor of the New York Stock
Exchange has run into a snag. Prosecutors said they could not prove
how much the defendants profited from the suspected scheme.


   TYCO AGREES TO ACQUIRE RAYCHEM


   Tyco International, the maker of electronic components, agreed
to buy Raychem, which makes wiring and tubing for industrial
electrical products. Tyco will pay $1.4 billion in cash, issue 16.1
million shares and assume $400 million in debt for Raychem, making
the deal worth $3.27 billion. Shares of Raychem soared $5.125, to
$36.25, on Wednesday.


   WHEN WORK BECOMES A TRADING PIT


   While much of the early concern about Internet abuse at the
workplace focused on pornography, the lure of the stock market has
overtaken it, some specialists said.


   FUND PROPOSAL MEETS OPPOSITION


   The Securities Industry Association, Wall Street's lobbying arm
in Washington, is encountering opposition to a recent proposal that
would make it easier for brokerage firms to buy and sell securities
with their own mutual funds without first seeking regulatory
approval, as they must do now. Market Place.


   LONG-TERM TREASURY RATES DECLINE


   Rates on long-term Treasury securities fell sharply Wednesday as
investors seemed to send a vote of confidence to the Federal
Reserve that it would keep inflation at bay. The yield on the
30-year bond fell to 5.80 percent from 5.88 percent Tuesday.


   STOCK PRICES GAIN


   Stock prices rose Wednesday on Fed-related optimism. The Dow
Jones industrial average rose 50.44 points, to 10,887.39; the
Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 10.91 points, to 1,344.23,
and NASDAQ composite index climbed 19.04 points, to 2,577.40.


   CHINESE TRY TO REASSURE AMERICANS


   Despite the anti-American demonstrations that erupted in Chinese
cities 10 days ago after the bombing of the Chinese embassy in
Yugoslavia, the effect on American business in China has been
moderate. Chinese officials like Shanghai Mayor Xu Kuangdi, who
traveled to a General Motors plant, met with foreign investors to
ease concerns.


   CAR-HAULING STRIKE IS THREATENED


   The Teamsters' union is threatening a strike by drivers against
the trucking companies that carry new cars to dealers. Such a move
would likely limit the selection of available vehicles but would
not affect the economy as much as a strike at an auto factory.


   SOFT DRINK DISTRIBUTOR SETTLES SUIT


   B.K. Miller, a soft drink distributor, has agreed to settle its
suit against Coca-Cola Enterprises for an undisclosed amount.


   LAWYER FINED IN CENDANT CASE


   A federal judge fined a lawyer $1,000 after finding he had
improperly disclosed confidential aspects of bidding by law firms
seeking the lead role in a suit against Cendant.

LAWMAKERS QUESTION CLAIM THAT OIL PRICES WILL DROP SOON 



   WASHINGTON _ Energy Secretary Bill Richardson withstood a
grilling from lawmakers over high oil prices Wednesday, as
legislators scorned his cautious forecast that oil-exporting
countries would increase production later this month and end a
year-long steep hike in fuel prices.


   Richardson, testifying before the House International Relations
Committee, rejected calls from lawmakers to quickly draw down
emergency government oil stocks, a move that advocates say would
lower prices. He said, however, as President Clinton did on
Tuesday, that that option was still ``on the table.''


   With the price of oil nearly tripled, to $31.77 a barrel in the
last year, and with drivers facing $2-a-gallon prices at the
gasoline pump this summer, the administration is under increasing
pressure to dip into the 600 million barrel Strategic Petroleum
Reserve in Louisiana and Texas.


   But Richardson repeatedly urged patience while talks continued
with the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and other
important producers like Mexico.


   ``We've got to be prudent and not overreact,'' he said, pointing
out that the emergency stocks were meant to be used only when
national fuel supplies were disrupted.


   ``I'm guardedly optimistic that OPEC will increase production
when it meets on March 27,'' Richardson said. He noted that the
Mexican oil minister said Wednesday in Paris that he favored a
production increase. Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Venezuela are also
considering increases.


   OPEC is considering increases of 1.2 million to 3.1 million
barrels a day, an about-face from production cuts of 4.3 million a
day that began in 1998 after the financial collapse in Asia. The
cartel now produces about 26 million barrels a day, or 35 percent
of the world's oil production.


   But lawmakers, especially those from the Northeast, Midwest and
California, dismissed the encouraging statements that Richardson
had elicited in talks with oil officials from Kuwait, Mexico,
Norway, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela on a weeklong trip.


   ``Bill, you came back with nothing,'' said Rep. Donald A.
Manzullo, R-Ill. ``You got no promises.''


   ``Congressman, I came back with quite a bit,'' Richardson, a
former Democratic representative from New Mexico, replied. ``Thirty
days ago, OPEC was saying its production cuts would continue. Now,
key members are saying they'll consider increases.''


   Even if OPEC votes to raise output at its March meeting, the big
questions are when and by how much. Typically, it takes six weeks
for production in the Middle East to pass through refineries and
reach local gas stations. ``We're running out of time,'' said Rep.
William Delahunt, D-Mass.

Richardson apparently did not use at least the threat of tapping
the strategic reserves to wring concessions from oil producers.


   ``Why on God's green earth didn't you add to your leverage by
opening that spigot?'' demanded Rep. Sam Gejdenson of Connecticut,
the panel's ranking Democrat.

intervening and manipulating the market,'' responded Richardson,
who said earlier that the negotiations were meant to ``convince,
not coerce.''

energy diplomacy work.''

 Jury Clears Supermarkets of Fixing 


	SAN DIEGO (AP) -- A jury Thursday cleared the three dominant  
Southern California grocery chains of charges they conspired to 
overcharge consumers for eggs. 


	After nearly five days of deliberations and six weeks of  
testimony, the San Diego County Superior Court jury voted 9-to-3 to 
clear Vons, Ralphs and Lucky Stores of conspiring to keep Southern 
California egg prices high between 1992 to 1997. 


	The class-action lawsuit could have cost the chains $267 million  
in damages under a state antitrust law granting the plaintiffs 
three times the amount of the alleged overcharge, which was 
calculated at between $83 million and $89 million. 


	Jury forewoman Kelly Briggs said the plaintiffs failed to  
convince enough jurors that the three competing grocery chains 
reached a back-room agreement to cheat consumers. 


	``They never gave us anything. There was no smoking gun,'' said  
Briggs, a corporate relations manager from Poway. 


	Several jurors said the stores' legal practice of checking and  
matching each other's prices could account for any similarities in 
the cost of a dozen eggs. 


	Don Howarth, one of the lawyers for the plaintiffs in the  
lawsuit said he was surprised and disappointed by the outcome. 
``It's a very hard verdict after a long trial,'' he said. 


	Howarth said the judge in the case could still rule that the  
grocery chains engaged in unfair competition as defined by the 
state Cartwright Act. 


	But a lawyer for Vons, Gregory Stone of San Diego, said the  
judge was unlikely to rule against the supermarkets given the 
jury's verdict in the trial. 


	``The jury was able to see that neither Vons nor the other  
defendants engaged in price fixing,'' Stone said. 


	Lawyers for the plaintiffs in the suit claimed that the stores  
in Southern California counties charged an average of between $1.99 
and $2.09 compared with prices as low as $1 per dozen elsewhere in 
the country. 


	They claimed the three conspired to keep the prices high in the  
counties of San Diego, Los Angeles, Orange, Riverside, San 
Bernardino and Imperial. This was accomplished, they argued, after 
an outbreak of avian flu in the early 1980s caused a spike in 
prices nationwide that eventually subsided in all regions but

BUSINESS AT A GLANCE 



   U.S. UNEMPLOYMENT RATE DECLINES TO A 30-YEAR LOW


   The Labor Department reported that the United States'
unemployment rate fell below 4 percent in April for the first time
in 30 years, as employers hired tens of thousands of census takers,
restaurant employees and temporary workers, and the robust economy
showed no signs of letting up.


   There was little evidence in the numbers _ a total of 340,000
new jobs last month and a 3.9 percent unemployment rate _ that the
record 9-year-old expansion might be weakening in response to the
Federal Reserve Board's attempt to slow the economy by raising
interest rates five times since last June.


   STOCK GAUGES RISE IN LIGHT TRADING


   Stocks rose on the lowest trading volumes of the year as
investors seemed to ignore the decline in the U.S. unemployment
rate. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 165.37 points, or 1.6
percent, to 10,577.86. The Nasdaq composite index finished up 96.58
points, or 2.6 percent, to 3,816.82, while the Standard & Poor's
500-stock index rose 23.06 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,432.63.


   CONCERNS GUILTY IN PRICE-FIXING CASE


   Four drug companies agreed to plead guilty and pay $33 million
in fines for taking part in an international conspiracy to fix
vitamin prices. The companies _ two American and two German _ are
the latest to plead guilty in the Justice Department's
investigation of the vitamin industry.


   BMW RAISES DOUBTS IN ROVER DEAL


   BMW of Germany raised new doubts about the likelihood of a deal
with Phoenix Consortium of Britain, which is supported by labor
unions and the British government, to rescue BMW's ailing Rover
Cars operations at one of the biggest auto plants in Britain.


   PHONE COMPANIES END MERGER TALKS


   Talks about a merger between two leading European
telecommunication companies _ Royal KPN of the Netherlands and
Telefonica of Spain _ broke down. The companies said that a
majority of the Telefonica board backed the deal but that
opposition ``by an important minority group within the board''
undermined KPN's confidence in the chance for success of the new
company.

   Cisco Systems agreed to buy ArrowPoint Communications in a stock
swap valued at $5.7 billion. The deal will give Cisco, the maker of
network equipment, the technology it needs to compete in the
fast-growing market for devices that can distribute Internet
content intelligently.


   OIL IS FOUND IN A BIG CASPIAN FIELD


   A consortium of nine foreign energy companies has found oil in a
huge Caspian Sea field and has resumed drilling to determine how
much exists. It will be at least another month before the drilling
establishes whether Kashagan has commercial volumes of oil.


   ADC TO BUY FIBER-OPTIC MAKERS


   ADC Telecommunications, a provider of technology that speeds the
transmission of voice, data and video signals, said it would buy
two European fiber-optic component makers. ADC, based in
Minnetonka, Minn., will pay $872 million in stock for the Swedish
laser maker Altitun and will pay roughly $80 million in cash for
Ibsen Micro Structures of Denmark.

Federal Trade Commission, Levi Strauss & Co. is trying to prevent
retailers from selling its jeans at deep discounts.


   Levi's blames plummeting sales on the erosion of its brand

disappointed in the brand's performance. The company also could
lose consumers who don't want to pay higher prices.

Levi's helps merchants pay for ``cooperative'' ads, which feature
the vendor's product and the stores' addresses.


   It may seem counterproductive for a supplier to oppose
attractive pricing of its merchandise. But the stakes are high:
Executives believe that the Levi's name is losing its legendary
status, arguably the company's most valuable asset.


   ``We're looking at a variety of initiatives to revitalize our

 Antitrust Head Klein Leaving Justice  
By MICHAEL J. SNIFFEN


   WASHINGTON (AP) -- Antitrust chief Joel I. Klein, who launched
the case to break up Microsoft and won record criminal fines
against international price fixers, will leave government at the
end of this month.


   ''The time has come to seek new challenges,'' Klein said in a
statement Tuesday. ''I have done what I set out to do here, and our
work is on the right track.''


   Klein, 53, intends to take time off and then begin a search for
his next job, Justice Department spokeswoman Gina Talamona said.


   Klein ''will not be wanting for suitors. His job search could be
one of the great auctions,'' predicted Professor William E. Kovacic
of The George Washington University Law School.


   During Klein's tenure, which began Oct. 18, 1996, the government
blocked or altered about 170 mergers. In 220 criminal price-fixing
cases, 52 executives were sent to prison, corporations paid $1.7
billion in fines and individuals paid another $21 million.


   Kovacic ranked Klein among the three most influential chiefs
ever to head the Justice Department's antitrust division, along
with Thurmond Arnold in the Roosevelt administration of the late
1930s and early 1940s and William Baxter in the first Reagan
administration in the early 1980s.


   ''He will be remembered as the man who brought the antitrust
division back into the courtroom after about 15 years of living on
settlements, guidelines and speeches,'' Kovacic said.


   Klein will leave before the courts render a final verdict on the
Microsoft case, but he won the first round. U.S. District Judge
Thomas Penfield Jackson ruled after a trial that Microsoft
illegally used monopoly power to thwart innovation by competitors
and ordered it split into two companies.


   Microsoft appealed the verdict and the Supreme Court is to
decide soon whether to hear the appeal directly, as Klein and
Jackson proposed, or to have the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for
the District of Columbia hear the appeal first, as the company
prefers.


   The full impact of Klein's litigation campaign won't be known
until appellate courts finally resolve the Microsoft case and
Klein's cases against American Airlines for predatory action
against low-cost competitors and against Visa and MasterCard for
limiting competition in credit cards.


   ''Joel Klein has been a champion for America's consumers. He has
fought tirelessly for marketplace competition, and Americans have
enjoyed better products, more choices and lower prices as a
result,'' said Attorney General Janet Reno.


   In cracking a worldwide vitamin price-fixing cartel, Klein's
division obtained the largest criminal fine in Justice Department
history for any kind of crime: $500 million levied against F.
Hoffmann-La Roche, a Swiss firm. BASF, a German firm, paid a $225
million fine in the vitamin case.


   The U.S. firm Archer Daniels Midland paid $100 million for
fixing the prices of food and feed additives lysine and citric
acid. For fixing the price of graphite electrodes used in mini
steel mills, SGL Carbon AG, a German firm, paid $135 million and
UCAR, a U.S. firm, paid $110 million.


   Opposition from Klein's division led to abandonment of an $11
billion merger between Lockheed Martin and Northup Grumman in the
defense electronics and strategic aircraft industries. WorldCom and
Sprint dropped their $129 billion telecommunications merger after
Klein and his staff objected to increased concentration in
long-distance, Internet backbone and business data services.


   In the last four years, Klein signed antitrust cooperation
agreements with Australia, Brazil, the European Union, Israel,
Japan and Mexico.


   The department announced that Klein's principal deputy, Doug
Melamed, 54, will replace him as acting assistant attorney general
in charge of the antitrust division.

 Congress Battles Over Dairy Pricing 


	WASHINGTON (AP) -- A battle among the nation's dairy farmers over  
the way that milk is priced has spilled over into Congress. 


	The fight, which could lead to an increase in retail milk  
prices, is over an Agriculture Department plan for modernizing its 
Depression-era dairy pricing system and a separate effort by 
farmers in the Northeast and South to fix prices on a regional 
basis. 


	The tussle is taking place both on the House floor and in a  
Capitol backroom where House and Senate negotiators are working on 
USDA's annual budget. 


	The House was expected to vote today to toss out USDA's new  
pricing system, which is set to take effect Oct. 1. It would cut 
consumer prices an estimated 2 cents a gallon while boosting income 
for farmers in the upper Midwest to the detriment of producers in 
the East and South. 


	Less certain was what the House-Senate conference committee  
that's working on the USDA spending bill would do with the issue. 


	Supporters of an alternative pricing system want to attach it to  
the must-pass spending measure along with authorization for the 
regional pricing cartels. 


	``Our nation's dairy farmers are in a crisis,'' said Rep. Thomas  
Reynolds, R-N.Y. The alternative plan ``is critical for the 
long-term viability of farming in most states.'' 


	But House GOP leaders want to keep the dairy issue out of the  
spending bill, lawmakers said, and that forced the conference 
committee to break up for the night Tuesday without an agreement on 
what to do. 


	Farmers in the East and South say the USDA plan would cost them  
as much as $200 million and drive many producers out of business. 
Producers overwhelmingly approved the plan in an August referendum, 
but opponents say that was only because there was no alternative 
for farmers to vote on. 


	``It was just a railroad job. ... Nobody wanted it, and nobody  
supported it,'' said Heck Davis, a Georgia dairy farmer. 


	The regional pricing organizations, such as one now operating in  
New England, set prices different than the federal system. The New 
England system is set to expire Oct. 1 unless Congress keeps it 
alive. 


	The issue has pitted Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., against fellow  
liberals like Sen. Herb Kohl and Rep. David Obey, Wisconsin 
Democrats who are among the chief Democratic negotiators on the 
appropriations measure. Kohl threatened to sidetrack the 
legislation if Leahy succeeds. 


	The issue also could pose a problem for some senators up for  
re-election next year, including Republicans Rod Grams of 
Minnesota, considered one of the most vulnerable GOP incumbents, 
and James Jeffords of Vermont. 


	Consumer groups back USDA's pricing plan and oppose the  
price-fixing compacts. 


	Under the government's current system, guaranteed minimum prices  
for fluid milk are lowest in the upper Midwest and highest in the 
South and West, up to $3 per hundred pounds higher in some places, 
because the price is based on a farm's distance from Eau Claire, 
Wis. 


	USDA's new plan would narrow the pricing disparities and throw  
out the Eau Claire system. 


	The current system was designed to spur production in areas  
where it had been scarce. But today, milk can easily be trucked by 
refrigerated truck from one region to another, according to 
supporters of the plan. 


	All but six states are covered by the federal system:  
California, Virginia, Wyoming, Montana, Hawaii and Alaska.

   WASHINGTON _ The Federal Trade Commission charged Monday that
Mylan Laboratories, one of the world's biggest makers of generic
drugs, had violated antitrust laws, and the government said it
would seek $120 million in refunds for consumers of two medications

   Attorneys general from 10 states planned to file a lawsuit

   The commission said Mylan had entered illegal agreements with
one of its suppliers to eliminate competition in the market for the
two generic drugs. Doctors write more than 21 million prescriptions
a year for the medications.


   Mylan denied all the charges. Milan Puskar, chairman of the
Pittsburgh-based company, said the commission's action was
``radical, rushed and wrong.''


   Mylan's shares dropped $3.3125, to $26.75, in New York Stock
Exchange trading after the accusations were announced.


   The government asserts that after locking up the supply of raw

   ``Mylan's outrageous price increases have cost consumers at
least $120 million in higher prices,'' said William Baer, director
of the agency's bureau of competition. Patients, many of them
elderly, take these drugs for long periods, and it may be dangerous

number of consumer complaints,'' more than any other issue in the
last four years, as well as a large number of protests from members

University basketball point-shaving scheme was indicted,

already completed.

three races in which he had bet. They claimed he helped other
drivers place second or third in two of those races.

   WASHINGTON (AP) -- Antitrust chief Joel I. Klein, who launched

OPEC IS BACK _ BIGGER AND BADDER THAN EVER  
 



   OPEC is back, and it is bigger and badder than ever. Or so it
would seem, to judge by the spectacular surge in oil prices in
recent months.


   Since the cartel met in March to agree to production cuts,
prices have almost doubled, to nearly $24 a barrel. Could the next
OPEC meeting, in Vienna on Sept. 22, pave the way for even higher
prices?


   The discipline demonstrated by the cartel, and by Mexico and
Norway, which also agreed to big production cuts, has surpassed
observers' wildest expectations _ including, it must be admitted,
this newspaper's.


   Now more upward pressure on prices looms. Asia's economies are
rebounding and America's strong expansion is continuing apace. Some
economists expect hoarding of oil stocks in response to the Year
2000 bug scare. And the onset of winter in the northern hemisphere
should keep demand up.


   Yet some people think that the current price rise has less to do
with OPEC than with America.


   Peter Odell, an oil watcher, argues that America last year
pushed key OPEC members to agree to production cuts for fear that
low prices might bankrupt such important countries as Venezuela and
Russia. ``OPEC,'' he maintains, ``is merely the instrument to bring
these players on board.''


   As conspiracy theories go, how plausible is this? ``We never
interfere in prices in any way,'' retorts one American official,
insisting that her government leaves them to be set in the markets.
But she concedes that the United States likes to see oil prices at
between $17 and $21 a barrel.


   That is a range which she reckons is ideal for stability in the
world market: much lower means producers go bust, much higher might
lead to inflation and consumer unrest.


   Ask what would happen if prices soar this winter towards $30,
and the reply remains elusive: ``We will do what we can to maintain
stability in the markets.''


   That sounds like a warning to the OPEC ministers gathering in
Vienna. In any case, OPEC's newfound unity looks as though it could
be as brief as it was unexpected. Internal divisions have already
surfaced.


   Some countries want to stick with the current agreement, which
sets binding quotas until next March. But two rival strategies
threaten to disrupt the proceedings.


   Saudi Arabia and Mexico are suggesting that the focus of the
accord should shift from production quotas to stock levels. They
argue that, once the world's oil stocks have fallen back to
end-1997 levels, countries could safely raise production without
jeopardizing prices.


   Their opponents fear that this could clear the way for OPEC's
perennial cheats to throw open the taps. Other countries want to
stop prices from rising too far, because that would upset such
powerful customers as the United States.


   Hugo Chavez, Venezuela's strongman, declared on Sept. 14 that
``right now, oil prices are at a satisfactory level for producers
and consumers. We do not want high prices, we need to avoid
fluctuations.''


   To smooth out volatility, Venezuela has been championing the
idea of aiming at a price band rather than production quotas,
meaning that the cartel would adjust production whenever prices
approached either limit of the range.


   Rivals retort that such a scheme would be too hard to implement
or police.

has been made harder by speculators. Philip Verleger, an oil
economist, notes that, since March, speculators on the futures
markets have bought the equivalent of at least 260 million barrels

nature of the oil-price rise, he argues, if OPEC ministers decided
to boost output they would send prices crashing temporarily.


   ``Their hands are tied,'' he says. But if they do nothing, stock
levels look likely to fall so low that an OPEC production increase
could take place as early as November.

LESLIE WORTHINGTON, 96, FORMER U.S. STEEL CORP PRESIDENT 



   Leslie B. Worthington, who as president of U.S. Steel Corp.
guided the company out of a prolonged steelworkers' strike and into
a confrontation with President John F. Kennedy over the industry's
's attempt to raise steel prices, died Aug. 3 at his home in
Ligonier, Pa. He was 96.


   The son of a coal miner who came to the United States from
England with his family in 1907, Worthington was elected the eighth
president of the country's largest steel manufacturer on Nov. 10,
1959.


   At the time, U.S. Steel was four months into a six-month strike
by steelworkers, then the longest strike in the industry's history.
The labor dispute was settled in January 1960 after intervention by
Vice President Richard Nixon and Labor Secretary James Mitchell.


   Even for someone who had spent his entire career in the steel
industry, Worthington's move to the top ranks of corporate America
came earlier than expected. His predecessor, Walter Mumford, had
been president of U.S. Steel for only a few months in 1959 when he
accidentally inflicted a knife wound on himself. A day after
undergoing surgery to repair the wound, Mumford suffered a stroke.
He died shortly thereafter.


   At the time of Worthington's appointment, observers on Wall
Street expected him to fight a pitched battle against the low-cost
imported steel that was dogging the industry. Like the company
founder Charles M. Schwab, Worthington's background was in sales,
rather than manufacturing. He joined Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corp.
as a sales apprentice in 1923 after graduation from the University
of Illinois, and worked his way up through the marketing ranks,
heading the company's sales offices in St. Paul, Minn.; Detroit and
Pittsburgh.


   In 1942, Worthington moved to U.S. Steel Supply Corp. as a vice
president, becoming president in 1946, a post he held for 11 years.
In 1957, he was named president of the company's big
Columbia-Geneva Steel division in San Francisco.


   After taking over as president and a director of the parent
company in 1959, Worthington remained second-in-command to U.S.
Steel chairman Roger Blough. But as head of the company's executive
committee, Worthington was most often the company's public face.


   As such, he used the wage increases granted to steelworkers in
1960 and again in 1962 as an opportunity to engage in a battle of
wills with the Kennedy administration, which had chastised the
steel industry for failing to make enough investments in new plants
and equipment.


   Worthington countered by arguing that the industry's real
problems were caused by cheaper imports, made overseas by workers
who earned less than one-third the $32 a day paid to American
steelworkers, and from domestic manufacturers of rival materials,
like aluminum and plastics.


   The confrontation reached a culmination in April 1962, when U.S.
Steel announced its first price increase in four years, raising the
price of steel mill products by $6 a ton, to $176.


   The move shocked and enraged Kennedy, who attacked the increase
as ``a chilling and irresponsible defiance of the nation's
interest'' and ordered a federal grand jury investigation of U.S.
Steel under the Sherman Antitrust Act.


   After three days of rhetoric and negotiation, which included a
move by the Defense Department, the biggest steel buyer in the
nation, to divert purchases to other manufacturers, U.S. Steel
followed the lead of several smaller steel makers in rescinding the
price increase.


   But that was not the end of the acrimony. Two weeks later, U.S.
Steel and Bethlehem Steel Co. were indicted on charges of violating
federal antitrust laws. Federal officials said the indictment had
nothing to do with the aborted price increase, but again in
September 1962, U.S. Steel was one of 15 companies named in a
federal indictment for conspiracy to fix prices of plastic hose and
pipe.

   LONDON _ Paul Cheringou, a Frenchman, buys his in Spain. In
London, Ken Reddy, a Briton, prefers to pop over _ or rather under

FIXING THE BLAME FOR GLOBAL ECONOMIC CRACKUPS 



   DAVOS, Switzerland _ Among the movers and shakers gathered here
for the World Economic Forum, a striking metaphor is helping to
frame the debate over the global financial crisis that began in
Asia and has spread to several other developing countries. The
debacle, some say, brings to mind a slick stretch of highway, scene
of a half-dozen recent auto accidents. So is it careless driving or
the highway that is the cause of the accidents?


   Substitute freewheeling worldwide capital flows and unrestricted
lending for the slippery, fast-moving highway. Make South Korea,
Thailand, Indonesia, Russia and Brazil stand-ins for the drivers
and their cars. The accidents are the panics and recessions _ the
crackups _ that have devastated each of these countries. And the
question now so widely debated is simple enough: Are the countries
mostly to blame or the unrestricted capital flows, or both?


   After the first accidents, the countries came in for almost all
the blame. It was because of crony capitalism, bad banking and
overleveraged real estate investments, many experts said. Fix the
sloppy financial practices and also make enough bailout money
available when a country gets into trouble _ basically the current
strategy of the International Monetary Fund for Brazil _ and the
accidents will be avoided or, at worst, will be mere fender
benders.


   But spectacular wrecks have occurred with alarming frequency and
severity in the last 18 months, even in Brazil, and some who had
mostly blamed the countries have begun to argue, here and in
earlier interviews, that the system needs serious fixing, too.


   The Clinton administration had placed most of the blame on the
countries, and still does. But its view, like that of the IMF, is
starting to reflect a more nuanced appraisal. ``We have seen that
countries need to pursue sounder policies and avoid lurching for
short-term capital, as Mexico and Thailand did,'' said Lawrence
Summers, the deputy treasury secretary. But in a phone interview
this week from Washington, he also called for ``more prudence on
the part of the lenders.''


   And in the administration's most direct acknowledgment so far
that it is not necessarily always committed to unrestricted capital
flows, he added: ``Where countries have controls that restrict
short-term lending, we have not in general sought to dismantle
them.''


   Some on Wall Street are similarly shifting ground. ``It is
appropriate to certainly consider fixing the system,'' said Stephen
Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. Morgan
Stanley normally makes more money when capital flows freely and the
firm can lend where and how it sees best.


   But the recent string of crackups has given Roach second
thoughts. ``I am not completely convinced that restrictions on the

clearly been a precipitant of these crises.''

limit the flow of short-term foreign loans to developing countries,
loans that often contributed to more rapid growth but which piled
up in huge amounts in Asia, Russia and Brazil. Then, at the first

worsening a full-scale financial collapse.

pursing flexible exchange rates, for example, to avoid sudden,
frightening devaluations; introducing bankruptcy laws that let
companies deep in foreign debt borrow and resume operations even
before they pay off the old debts; and standstill provisions in
lending agreements that would temporarily prevent a foreign lender
from withdrawing loans from a South Korea or a Brazil in the midst
of a crisis.

carefully early on and suffer more of the consequences later if
